TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Air Landing Fee: New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament:

This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the proposed air landing fee for regional and commuter airlines landing at Sydney Mascot Airport during peak times discriminates severely against people in rural Australia and will force many airlines to either revise their schedules, cancel flights or increase passenger fares to cover this additional financial impost of the Federal Labor Government. This will result in less accessibility for country businessmen and travellers alike, will increase the costs of business for rural people and threatens the viability of many smaller airlines who provide valuable services to rural towns. We therefore call on the Federal Government to abolish all plans for the introduction of this discriminatory fee and allow commuter airlines to continue to provide their full range of services to towns throughout New South Wales.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Farm Exemption
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators in Parliament. The petition of the undersigned shows:

That the Government is planning to introduce an assets test on Family Allowance at a level of $500,000. It will maintain the current assets tests on Family Allowance Supplement (FAS), Austudy and Isolated Children's Allowance which are discriminating against farming families particularly during the present rural crisis.

Your Petitioners ask that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Australian Government to exempt the family farm of registered primary producers who are living and working on their own farm from inclusion in the assets tests for Austudy, Family Allowance, Isolated Children's Allowance and Family Allowance Supplement.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medical Centres
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable senators and members assembled in Parliament:-
The petition of certain residents of Western Sydney draws the attention of the Parliament to the proposed legislation which may prevent x-ray services being available at medical centres.

Your petitioners therefore request the Parliament to allow qualifying medical centres to continue to attract Medicare benefits for x-rays performed at those centres, so that this worthwhile service to the community will be able to continue.

PETITION.TITLE: Wealth Inquiry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned shows:

That in Australia, the rich are getting richer while poverty is increasing, as shown by recent research that 10% of the population own 50% of the wealth while people in poverty have increased from 1.5 million in 1982 to 2.1 million in 1986.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should:
Request the Australian Government-
to establish a Wealth Inquiry as a first and essential step to the achievement of a more just society;
and that this Inquiry should seek to establish-
the current distribution of wealth, how it has changed over time and the causes of these changes
the effectiveness of the Australian taxation system in raising revenue at all levels of taxpayers' income and assets
the measures which should be taken to achieve a more just society

PETITION.TITLE: X-rated and Violent Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. The petition of citizens of Australia points out:

that all State Governments, States Attorneys-General, most women's groups and the majority of men in Australia, including significant numbers of members of Parliament, are totally opposed to the importation and distribution of `X' and excessively violent `R'-rated video pornography in Australia;
that most `X'-rated material available in Australia is imported;

that the Federal Government, by its Customs power under the Constitution, and not the Australian Capital Territory Government, is solely responsible for controlling the importation of this pornographic material;
that by continuing to allow the importation of such pornographic material, the Federal Government is neglecting its responsibility to the women, children and families of Australia.
Your petitioners, therefore, request the Senate to:
1. Ban `X'-rated pornographic material at the point of entry into Australia;
2. Exclude from the `R'-rating all gratuitously violent material.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium: Mining and Export
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That your petitions request that the Australian Government take steps immediately to stop the mining and export of uranium.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The States Grants (General Purposes) Bill 1990 has four purposes. First of all, its essential purpose is to put in place arrangements for the provision of general purpose assistance to the States and the Northern Territory in 1990-91, consistent with the decisions taken at the Premiers Conference in June. Secondly, the Bill effectively determines the payments to be made to local governments for general purposes under the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Act. Thirdly, the Bill makes provision for machinery adjustments for the transfer of the debits tax to the States. Finally, the Bill makes provision for recoupment of State contributions for higher education superannuation and recoupment of moneys where there is a breach of higher education funding conditions as outlined in the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill, which has not been debated in the Senate, although it has gone through the House of Representatives. It will come here later.

SPEECH.PARA: First of all, let me say that the coalition has no problems with the first of these purposes, namely, to put in place the machinery arrangements for the provision of general purposes assistance to the States and the Northern Territory as agreed at the Premiers Conference. It is clear that at the Premiers Conference the Commonwealth should have been tougher on the States in terms of the total arrangements negotiated, taking into account all the payments that go to the States, but the Commonwealth itself has proven to be even more lax in terms of its own purpose outlays than was apparent at the time of the conference. It would be unjust to inflict an even heavier burden on the States when the Commonwealth itself is unprepared to take the necessary fiscal measures to put those measures in line with the needs of this economy, an economy which is, as we all know now-and even the Government has at last admitted it-heavily recessed as a result of Government policies: a recession engineered quite deliberately by the Government at great cost and hardship to every Australian.

Commonwealth spending in real terms has increased dramatically since this Government came to office. I will come back to that in a moment. There certainly has been no equity between the Commonwealth and the States so far as restraint is concerned. I have circulated and now move on behalf of the Opposition a second reading amendment in the following terms:
At end of motion, add: ``, but the Senate:

(a) notes that while some States have not done enough to use efficiently and effectively their own-source revenues, they have nevertheless borne the brunt of the Commonwealth Government's fiscal restraint and condemns the Commonwealth Government for its inability to make appropriate reductions in its own-purpose spending; and
(b) condemns the Commonwealth Government for strengthening its dominance over the States by providing an increasing proportion of its payments in tied form.''.

I move that amendment because, as I have said, the amount of restraint that has been exercised by the Commonwealth in terms of its own spending over the period of this Government has been minimal. One of the great cons, I believe, of the politics of the last eight years is the impression that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Government seem to have been able to get across in the community that this Government has been a government of fiscal restraint.

Nothing could be further from the truth. Commonwealth spending in real terms since this Government came to power has increased by 32.4 per cent, while State expenditures over the same period have increased by only 10.2 per cent. At the same time, State revenues have increased by 23.8 per cent but Commonwealth revenues in real terms have increased by 38.6 per cent, almost 50 per cent more. On top of that, Commonwealth payments to the States have declined by 5.3 per cent in real terms over that period. For 1990-91, the year which is the focus of attention for this Bill, the States as a whole have budgeted to hold expenditure more tightly than the Commonwealth. They have not budgeted to hold it as tightly as they should, but they have nevertheless budgeted to hold it more tightly than the Commonwealth.

States' expenditure this year is to increase by 6.1 per cent compared with growth in the Federal Government's own purpose outlays this year-money being spent on its own programs-of a quite profligate and excessive 11.9 per cent. So much for the Government's boasting or claims of fiscal restraint. It is simply not true.

The Government's spending on its own purpose programs this year is going to go up by 12 per cent-11.9 per cent-at a time when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer are telling all Australians that they have to pull their belts in and lower their standards of living because of the policies of this Government. While that is happening, the Government is going on its profligate and excessive way, spending very large increases.

Those figures reveal an excessive aggregate increase in public sector outlays in 1990-91 which is quite inconsistent with the need for overall fiscal restraint. The Commonwealth has to bear much of the blame for this as it has again been unprepared to shoulder its own fair share of the fiscal burden. The Commonwealth should have been prepared at least to be as tough on itself as it has been on the States. The figures that I have just quoted blow quite out of the water the Treasurer's contention that it is the States that are the financial vandals, to use a term coined by the Queensland Premier, Wayne Goss. Far from that being the truth, the real economic vandal on the Australian scene is the Commonwealth Government with, of course, its Labor State counterparts, particularly in Victoria and Western Australia.

This is all the more true since the release of the latest financial transactions statement by the Government which provides quite clear evidence of a Commonwealth Budget blow-out. It is also clear that the processes involved at the Premiers Conference negotiations are quite inappropriate in terms of the requirements that we have for a sophisticated approach to financial management and fiscal policy in this nation.

It was said last month by Western Australian Labor Premier Lawrence-and I would agree with this statement; it is one of the few statements of Premier Lawrence's that I would agree with-of the Premiers Conference:

Despite its increasing significance, we still have this extraordinary ritual whereby the Commonwealth's offer to the States is placed under Premiers' doors before breakfast on the day of the conference, leaving no time for meaningful discussion and negotiation.

That, of course, is actually what happens. Two hours before the Premiers Conference starts, the Commonwealth slips under the doors of Premiers' bedrooms in Canberra the actual offer documents that are to be negotiated and which involve taxpayers' money to the tune of up to $25 billion. That is the way in which financial negotiations have been going on in this country. It is an appalling state of affairs. I am glad to say that steps appear to be in the process of being taken to have the conduct of future Premiers Conferences and Loan Council meetings changed. Such reforms have been long overdue.

As a result of the recent Special Premiers Conference, the offer document from the Commonwealth to the States will in future be available to the States and the Territories two days prior to the conference. There will be more meaningful consultation involving all the parties before the document is produced in the first place. Whether that is a sufficient response to the serious situation that has prevailed for many years is something that we will have to look at and judge. But at least it is a step in the right direction and it is welcomed by the coalition.

The level of general purpose payments to be paid under the Bill that we are now debating is currently estimated to be $13,508m. That is about 15 per cent of Commonwealth Budget outlays in 1990-91. The payments are of this large magnitude because of the degree-to use the jargon of today-of vertical fiscal imbalance in Australia which arises out of the imbalance between the financial resources available to each tier of government and the expenditure responsibilities they are expected to meet. Currently, the Federal Government collects around 80 per cent of total taxation revenue in Australia, whilst being directly responsible for around only 50 per cent of total general government expenditures. A paper recently released by the Economic Planning Advisory Council (EPAC) states that the financial arrangements have been the major obstacle to rationalising intergovernmental duplication. The EPAC paper has expressed particular concern about the Commonwealth's dominance of the taxation arena and the increasing emphasis on conditional or tied funding.

It is not surprising that the system that we have is fraught with problems. The current arrangements for Commonwealth-State financial arrangements have developed in an ad hoc fashion since Federation as circumstances have dictated. Successive piecemeal changes have been made without due regard to the overall impact on the entire system of financial arrangements.

The Special Premiers Conference that was held recently was essentially prompted by the calls of the coalition earlier this year for a fundamental revamp, reshape and relook at the whole area of Commonwealth-State relations. I am pleased to say that the Government responded to those calls of Dr Hewson and the coalition. As a result of that we have had one Special Premiers Conference and that has given some hope that the system of financial relations arrangements will be fully reviewed.

Unfortunately, the terms of reference for the working group set up at that first conference that has been given the task of reviewing the distribution of Commonwealth and State taxing powers, appears to be more restrictive than we would have wished it to be. Of course, the proof of the pudding will be in the eating. We will have to wait and see whether that working group is prepared to take on more than a Clayton's review of this central issue.

Certainly, the Commonwealth must be in a position to pursue an overall effective fiscal policy. But the undeniable fact of the matter, as I have said, is that the Commonwealth in recent years has passed on to the States much of the burden of fiscal restraint. A profligate State can do damage to macro-economic management, just as can a profligate central government. While that is the case, concentrating the taxing powers in the hands of one government-the Commonwealth-means, of course, technically and theoretically, that much greater havoc can be caused by a single player in the game than if the revenue raising and expenditure burden were more equally distributed. One only has to look at the profligacy of the Whitlam Government and this Government in several of its Budgets in the 1980s to see the damage that can be done.

The payments in this Bill are lower than would otherwise have been the case because of the growth this year in the proportion of tied payments made to the States. The Bill we are debating today relates only to general purpose payments to the States-that is, payments that are made without strings attached to them. The figures, therefore, for these general purpose payments are lower than would otherwise have been the case because this year there has been a very significant increase in the proportion of funds that are paid to the States on conditional terms-in other words, tied payments. That is a matter of very considerable concern to the coalition and to the States. It is one of the great issues that will require review in the revamping and reforming of Commonwealth-State financial arrangements.

Since 1982-83, when this Government came to power, specific purpose payments-that is, tied payments-have increased from 36 per cent of total Commonwealth payments to the States to an estimated 50 per cent in 1990-91. This has meant less freedom for the States to determine their own expenditure priorities. It has also meant more Canberra bureaucrats determining the priorities of State and Territory governments with more red tape inhibiting rational policy options. Again, in looking at this issue some progress seems to have been made. It was agreed at the recent Premiers Conference that the inefficiencies caused by the escalation in the proportion of tied grants being paid to the States should be reviewed. It is essential that something meaningful comes out of that review.

As I said at the outset, the next purpose of this Bill is to make provisions for payments to local government from the Commonwealth. The coalition has no difficulty with that proposition. Again, it is of a traditional machinery nature and I will not pursue it any further. Nor do we have any difficulties with that part of the Bill which makes a machinery provision for transfer of the debits tax to the States. The Debits Tax Termination Bill 1990 is to be debated later today and I will leave my comments on this aspect until the Senate considers that Bill.

The final purpose of the States Grants (General Purposes) Bill relates to the conditions which the States must meet in order to receive their full entitlements under this Bill. This is a matter of great concern to the coalition. I refer in particular to clause 12, which aims to allow the recoupment of any payments due to the Commonwealth as a result of States breaching conditions to be instituted under the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill 1990, which is yet to be debated in this place. This Bill effectively requires the States to continue to comply with compulsory student unionism and, if they do not, to pay the Commonwealth, either directly or through reductions in general revenue payments under the States Grants (General Purposes) Bill, any costs arising from non-compliance under the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill.

That proposition is quite repugnant to the coalition. We will move an amendment in committee, which I have circulated, to delete clause 12 of the States Grants (General Purposes) Bill. I will speak more about it in committee and will explain the total opposition we have in principle to the concept contained in clause 12. Setting aside for the moment the principle involved in the question of student unionism, and whether it should be compulsory or not, there are other things that have to be said about having clause 12 as part of this Bill.

First, the clause should not be part of a general purposes payments Bill. This Bill is supposed to deal essentially with matters that were agreed to at the Premiers Conference. The question of penalising States depending on their view on student unionism was not a matter agreed to at the Premiers Conference. It had nothing to do with the Premiers Conference and was not raised at the Premiers Conference. To have this clause tagged into this Bill is nothing more than a blatant attempt to blackmail the States to go along with the enforcement of compulsory student unionism. It is indicative of the paternalism that has come to characterise so much of the relationship between the Commonwealth and the States, which is not conducive to an atmosphere of co- operation required if the current review of Commonwealth-State relations is even to start being successful.

The Government's action in tagging this matter onto this particular Bill is a quite blatant misuse of legislative procedures for political ends. The Government was hoping somehow to sneak this clause through by putting it in a piece of legislation to which it clearly should not relate. If this clause is agreed to, then it will set very dangerous precedents indeed for the whole future legislative process in this nation because it will mean that governments of the day will attempt to get through pieces of legislation in particular areas which do not necessarily have anything to do with the prime purpose of the Bill at hand.

I have raised this matter widely, including with the Australian Democrats. I hope the Democrats will treat this matter as seriously as the Opposition does because if clause 12 is allowed to proceed and to continue in this Bill, then the precedents for the future are very dangerous indeed. It is ironic that, as a result of clause 12, these so-called general purpose funds are now being tied. We have seen the thin edge of the wedge here with recoupment for higher education superannuation and some other one-off recoupment clauses being used in the past.

Unfortunately, it seems that tagging on special conditions to this Bill is becoming more of a first rather than a last resort option for the Commonwealth to recoup moneys it considers itself to be entitled to. It is a further abuse of the financial dominance that the Commonwealth has sought progressively over the years. The Hawke Government has elevated it to an art form to produce this dominance over the States.

The Government has also not given due regard to the extent to which such conditions complicate the already extremely complex calculation of payments to the States. It will be another blow to transparency in payments to the States; it will make accountability that much more difficult; and it will make the whole process of Commonwealth-State financial relations that much more complicated, complex and difficult and, therefore, unsatisfactory.

The coalition will be opposing clause 12 on the grounds of principle in relation to an Act which is supposed to deal with general purpose or untied funds, and also because of the abhorrent nature of the conditions which the Government is attempting to force on the States. I will speak more on that matter in committee.

The coalition supports this Bill with the exception of that provision contained in clause 12. We feel so strongly about clause 12 that if it remains not only will we be opposing it in committee but also we shall vote against the Bill at the third reading.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today the Senate is discussing the States Grants (General Purposes) Bill 1990. The payment of general revenue assistance in 1990-91 represents a cut of some $400m from the Forward Estimates. This represents a 3.7 per cent reduction and thus continues a trend of annual cuts in general revenue assistance to the States since 1987-88. Much of the so-called savings announced by the Commonwealth in its various economic statements have consisted of cuts to general purpose payments to the States over this period.

SPEECH.PARA: As has occurred in earlier years, additional funding has been provided to the Northern Territory to assist with its budgetary situation. This funding, however, has come from the overall pool of funds, which represents a contribution by the other States to the Northern Territory. Thus it is a reflection of the closed system of funding which has operated since the early 1980s rather than the open-ended system which operated up to the 1980s whereby the provision of additional assistance required an additional input of funds from the Commonwealth.

At the 1990 Premiers Conference the Commonwealth gave a qualified guarantee to keep State general revenue assistance constant in real terms from 1991-92 to 1993-94, the qualification being that this would only apply if there were no major deterioration in Australia's economic circumstances. Thus, we must now put a substantial question mark over that commitment, with the attendant uncertainty for State budgetary considerations.

It might be noted that the last time such a guarantee was given was in 1985-86, when the Commonwealth pledged that in 1986-87 and 1987-88 general revenue funding would be increased by 2 per cent in real terms. That guarantee was kept for 1986-87, although substantial cuts were made to general purpose capital funding, while the Government reneged on the promise for 1987-88, claiming that the need for economic stringency would not permit the guarantee to be met. It seems to us that we are in danger of moving into a similar situation where States once again will be starved of necessary funds.

From 1987-88 until the present, funding has been given on a purely annual basis, with no indication of future funding arrangements. Obviously, this has presented many problems to the States in terms of forward planning. The present approach of the Commonwealth Grants Commission will be to base its relativities recommendations on a review of the last five years financial results of the States rather than the previous three years. While this approach will smooth the changes in relativities, it means that relativities will now be based in part on State Budget results which are quite old and may not bear much resemblance to current budgetary conditions.

As we know, the Commonwealth Grants Commission has just completed a report on fiscal equalisation, and this will form the basis of discussion on Grants Commission methodology in the run-up to the next major review of relativities, which will occur in 1993. Of course, in the meantime, the process of annual updates will continue.

The Commonwealth has continued the process of requiring its authorities to pay taxes, fees and charges to the States and local government. This has already been done to a great extent, but provision has been made this year for motor vehicle taxes of Telecom Australia and Australia Post to be paid to the States. As in previous years, the Commonwealth is clawing back some 90 per cent of such taxes by reducing grants to the States, and this year the recoupment has taken the form of reduction in capital grants. While this process places authorities on a more similar basis to private enterprises, it nevertheless has had the effect over recent years of enabling the Commonwealth to shift outlays off budget. Thus, to a large extent, a feature of the Government's deregulation program is to give up an ever greater slice of responsibility and control over our economy.

As I mentioned earlier, State general purpose assistance has been cut on an annual basis over the past few years. Some States have argued that this has made it difficult for them to undertake the types of outlays-such as expenditure on infrastructure, redundancy payments, et cetera-required to achieve the sort of micro-economic reform which the Commonwealth would like to see achieved. Some States have had to increase taxes and charges, with consequent impact on inflation, while other States have borrowed funds to fund general Government outlays of a non self-financing nature. As we all know, this has placed the finances of a couple of States into difficulties.

In recent years, the Commonwealth has again begun to place specific conditions on the provision of general purpose assistance to the States. For example, Queensland was threatened with reduced funding if it did not meet the global borrowing limits imposed by its authorities. Other conditions have related to higher education superannuation contributions and the like. As Senator Short said, it should be noted that this Bill also imposes conditions relating to higher education funding.

The Australian Democrats have carefully considered in detail the arguments put forward by the Opposition on clause 12. After consideration, we have decided not to support the Opposition in its attempt to delete clause 12. However, I foreshadow amendments to be moved to the higher education legislation by my colleague Senator Bell to ensure that students who object to the arrangements, where funds could be used for political activities of the student organisations, will be able to opt out. Their contributions will be channelled totally into services provided by educational institutions.

We believe it is important that we continue an incentive for students to remain members of what is after all their governing body within a tertiary institution. Thus we will make it possible for individuals to opt out of an obligation to join the student association and to have a portion of its service fee applied to activities which they may not agree to. We believe it is a right that individuals should have. Nevertheless, we believe that the overall concept of supporting the student organisations, which play an important role in the life of a tertiary institution, should be supported.

It is necessary to advert to the lunacy of States competing against each other to attract investments and any short term gain which that may yield. The competition involves taxation, environmental standards, workers' safety or a combination of these things-most of them with long term costs. We need to eliminate such ridiculous auctions. A recent one involving my own State was the disgraceful action of Mr Greiner in bowing to the tobacco lobby and stealing the Australian Motor Cycle Grand Prix from Phillip Island. This caused increased costs to New South Wales taxpayers and will cost the Victorian economy in future years; all just to appease corporate interests. I refer to an edition of the Sun-Herald of 2 December 1990, in which it is clearly stated:
The dream has turned into a financial nightmare for Greiner and his government. Costs have accelerated sharply to more than $60m and are still rising.
The article refers to the Eastern Creek raceway, to which Mr Greiner committed himself so that he was able to steal from Victoria the Motor Cycle Grand Prix.

Having regard to the decisions made at the last largely constructive Premiers Conference, the area of non-bank financial institutions is still disappointing. All that emerged from the Premiers Conference was a somewhat pathetic proposal vaguely similar to the failed cooperative model tried in the company law area, which has now been abandoned by this Parliament. I remind the Senate that I have introduced the Financial Corporations (Prudential Standards) Amendment Bill which seeks to complete the work of this Parliament. We believe we must do better for depositors in non-banking financial institutions than we are doing now. Their deposits must be secure and the institutions must be supervised to ensure that guarantees can be extended.

Another area which is at last receiving some attention is that of infrastructure. The Minister for Community Services and Health, Mr Howe, has brought into the public debate the need for more public investment in this country. Indeed, there is now a growing acceptance of the benefits of public infrastructure investment. I refer to the Economic Planning Advisory Council paper No. 33 entitled Economic Infrastructure in Australia, which found there was evidence of deficiencies in areas such as urban roads, airport facilities, telecommunications and railways. Pages 39 and 41 of the paper warned of problems emerging in the maintenance of existing assets such as water storage, distribution and waste disposal systems and referred to a number of studies which showed that potentially high returns were available in some specific areas of infrastructure investment. Add to this the horrendous over-investment in electricity generation and irrigation, with its appalling environmental legacy, and we have to realise that we must change our ways.

Public sector investment has declined markedly since the mid-1960s when it was almost 10 per cent of GDP. The Whitlam Government boosted the level up to about 9 per cent but since then decline has been rapid, apart from in the early 1980s. Currently the level has declined to a little over 6 per cent of GDP. A lot of fiscal restraint is exercised in this case by this Government simply cutting back essential public investment, both on its own account and on behalf of the States. It is clear that we need more public transport, much better waste disposal systems, better railways and so on.

The other noticeable trend is the increase in the proportion of investment by government business enterprises and the decline by the general government sector. To a limited extent this can be explained by corporatisation, which we do not object to and in fact support as a means of increasing the efficiency of government business enterprises. There remains within that increasing commercialisation and corporatisation the area of environmental concern and social consequences of a policy which pursues profit as its major incentive. As an example I point to the need to switch to public transport and railway systems.

A recent example of the trend which the Government appears to be accepting is its preparedness to reallocate some $250m earmarked originally for the Koonong Valley and Mullum Mullum Valley freeway in Melbourne to a railway to be built along the same line, providing much cheaper and environmentally less damaging public transport.
In conclusion, the Australian Democrats support the Government's Bill on States grants that is before the Senate today, subject to the reservations I have expressed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning I would like to direct most of my comments on the States Grants (General Purposes) Bill to the second part which deals with local government. I have had quite a number of representations from councils in my State of Tasmania which feel they have been seriously disadvantaged by the way the Federal Government is allocating funding. For instance, overall, Tasmanian councils will have received $19.022m for 1990-91. This represents a mere $450,000 more than they received last year. When these figures are adjusted to take account of inflation, it is clear that Tasmanian councils have received $1m less from the Federal Government than the amount they received last year. This can be put into an even worse context by comparing the national increase of 3.2 per cent with Tasmania's 2.2 per cent increase.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the major losers in Tasmania are the cities of Hobart and Launceston. This follows a similar situation that occurred last year when once again these cities were major losers. Hobart will receive $728,000, which represents a loss in real terms of $200,000 this year, whilst the city of Launceston in the north of the State has suffered a loss of $160,000, or around $300,000 in real terms. I am concerned, and I know that councils in Tasmania are concerned, that ultimately these costs are going to be passed on to the ratepayers.

A week or so ago in the Senate I referred briefly to the Commonwealth Grants Commission and more particularly to the inquiry by the Commonwealth Grants Commission into the distribution of financial assistance grants for local government throughout Australia. I have a particular concern that the principle of fiscal equalisation should continue to be adopted in relation to funding distribution. I know that there are States throughout Australia which do not have the capacity to raise revenues and increase costs to the same extent as other local government areas, and these States will be seriously disadvantaged by the use of the unweighted population as a base for determining the shares of the total Bill which makes up the financial assistance grants.

When fiscal equalisation principles occur, grants are made to local government areas so that when local government units are compared on a national level, they are able to provide services comparable to those in other States, provided they make a similar effort to raise taxes and charges. By this method we are able to guarantee that those States and Territories which suffer disadvantages receive a level of funding to compensate for these costs. The danger when funding is not allocated on a fiscal equalisation basis and some other relatively simple basis is used is that local government areas may be penalised unnecessarily, and similarly others may be assisted unintentionally. It continues to be important to assess the capacity of each State and therefore its local government authorities to raise the revenue required to fund its existence.

Previously in the Senate I have referred to, for example, the difference in real estate prices between Tasmania and the mainland. I believe that Tasmanian prices are, on average, half those of their mainland counterparts. This becomes even worse when we move away from the major metropolitan areas. For instance, in June 1990 the median price of a house in Sydney was $177,000 and in Melbourne, $133,000. This compares with Tasmania where the median price in the same period was $84,000. So quite obviously the amount of rates that can be raised from those properties is not as significant as it is in other States.

We also should remember that Tasmania does not have the level of commercial and industrial development which occurs on the mainland. When we compare all those factors it becomes apparent that the amount of rate income that can be generated by the other States is certainly different from what Tasmania can generate and there is a higher degree of effort required by Tasmanian councils.

On the other hand, whilst we have had reduced funding, local government has had the problem of greater expenditure because of the community's insistence on upgrading, for instance, the sewerage plants, as they have an expectation of the environment being improved. For instance, in my former city of Clarence they have just had to spend $1.5m, with little or no help from the State Government, on upgrading their sewerage plant.

The Commonwealth, through the Premiers Conference, as Senator Short said, has tried to enforce fiscal restraint on the States and local government. In fact, as Senator Spindler said earlier, in 1990 general revenue grants to the States were cut by $400m, or 2 per cent in real terms. On the other hand, the Commonwealth Government increased specific purpose grants by 4 per cent, but these specific purpose grants, of course, give more power to the Commonwealth and further dominance over the States.

The net effect is that Tasmania once again has suffered severe funding cuts by the Hawke Government. State funding has been reduced by more than $500m since the Australian Labor Party took control of the treasury bench in Canberra. Quite frankly, I get a bit sick of listening to the State Labor Premier in Tasmania complaining about the fiscal mess being caused by the previous Liberal Government when we know that funds to Tasmania were reduced by over $500m during the term of this Government. That is fair enough if the Commonwealth is showing the same restraint as it is expecting in States and local government areas, but unfortunately local government, as we all know, is at the end of the line. It cannot pass on its costs. It cannot pass on its problems because it is at the end of the line. Who will suffer? Of course, it is the ratepayer. The ratepayer is normally the head of a family. It is the same old story: it is the family that is getting hit.

We all know that local government is expected to provide services-roads, cleaning beaches, home help, water, sewerage, libraries, pest control, planning, street lighting, tourism facilities, public toilets, reserves, community arts, and community programs. These are just a few of the things that local governments are asked by the ratepayers to provide and are expected to provide. Who is the major funding source for all these things? Of course, it is the ratepayer. Reducing funding at the Commonwealth level means the councils are faced with the decision of whether to increase their rates or reduce their services.

I think it is as a result of this situation that last week there was on the front page of the Australian an article stating that some councils throughout Australia, because of the recession and the increased rate demands, are being forced to sell family homes. People who have owned their houses all their lives and who have battled through high interest rates and repayments are now being forced to sell their homes because they cannot afford to pay their rates. I think that sums up what I have been saying. At the end of the line the local government ratepayers get everything passed on to them.

I asked the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) a question about this problem the other day and I was interested in his answer. I appreciate his answer because he had gone to a lot of trouble. He said:
Local government, like the Commonwealth and the States, has had to shoulder its part of the burden of economic restraint.

We know that the States have had to shoulder the burden. We know that local government certainly has had to shoulder the burden. But I think figures show that certainly the Commonwealth has not shouldered the burden to the same extent. The Minister went on to say:
In some cases local government may need to put its own house in order.
I am sure that many councils around Australia would be very pleased to hear that sort of news!

Previously, the Tasmanian Government has made increased use of land tax. This is another impost on the ratepayer. Apart from having to pay rates, he now has the unenviable task of having to pay land tax on his property. In my own State of Tasmania, local government is required by law to collect also a number of rates and levies which are transferred to the State Government to fund library and fire protection services. On top of that, just recently the Field Labor Government has chosen to levy councils for the costs of providing services including planning and environment matters. In effect, councils will now be directly funding State Government obligations. I hope that the Commonwealth Government takes note of this: because it has reduced funding to the States, the States have passed costs on to local government. As I said before, local governments are at the end of the line; they have nowhere to pass costs except to the ratepayers.

I think this situation of collecting levies for planning and environment matters is unique to the State of Tasmania. I do not believe other State governments have put this impost on their ratepayers. While it might provide a windfall for the Field Government, it is certainly placing a heavy burden on those already hard done by ratepayers. I know for a fact that many councils will be issuing supplementary rate bills for $100 right on Christmas this year and I do not think the families in my former municipality will be very impressed.

As I said earlier, local governments are required to provide many services. Over recent years, councils have come to play an increasing role in the provision of children's services, services for the elderly and services for youth. In outlying areas of Tasmania, it is not uncommon for councils to assume almost all Federal Government responsibilities, and this certainly imposes another heavy cost in service provision. I noticed the other day that the Glenorchy City Council has just started a home and community care (HACC) scheme. My former council of Clarence has a HACC scheme. They are very good schemes and they provide very good services for the people, but at the end of the day it is the ratepayer who ends up funding them. Because Tasmania's population is growing extremely slowly, service provision will remain on a high cost per head basis.

Over the last three years, expenditure per capita by Tasmanian local governments on human and welfare services has increased by 77 per cent compared with a national increase of only 33 per cent. Of the 46 municipalities and cities in the State, 18 currently have some direct involvement in human services and housing programs. Because of the need to provide services, local government in Tasmania is using its untied revenues to broaden the range of responsibilities, despite the obvious factors making it difficult to raise revenue and the reduced share of untied financial assistance grants coming to the State.

I cannot stress strongly enough the effect which the loss of fiscal equalisation principles from the grant distribution to Tasmania is having and will have on our community. Tasmanians have always had a proud record of seeking to assist themselves where possible. However, clearly in this case there are a number of areas to which I believe special consideration should be given by the Government to improve funding arrangements to local government.

I remember talking to Professor Peter Self a couple of years ago about the report of his National Inquiry into Local Government Finance and its recommendations on how local government should be funded. Broadly speaking, I think the Government picked up the second option that he gave them, and that was on a population basis. He did say quite strongly that in his opinion, after having spent so much time looking at funding arrangements around Australia for local government areas, places like Western Australia and Tasmania in particular were in need of special assistance. Unfortunately, that has not occurred and we are seeing the results of it and will continue to see the results of it while we have the method of funding that is being used at the moment.

In conclusion, I would like to say once again how concerned I am that we are arriving at the situation where councils are being forced to sell ratepayers' homes to collect their rate bills. I think it is a pretty sorry state of affairs when we see that sort of thing happening in what was once a wonderful country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak only on clause 12 of the States Grants (General Purposes) Bill. Clause 12 has 16 lines. It is a disgraceful legislative proposal. We are totally opposed to these 16 lines. We in the Opposition are totally opposed to the whole concept of compulsory student unionism. This clause is in parallel with the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill, which we are to debate next week and which has already passed through the House of Representatives. That funding Bill proposes to place in the mechanism for passing on billions of dollars to our universities and colleges an amendment that says that the money is available in full to those universities only if there is nothing in them to bar compulsory student unionism.

SPEECH.PARA: There have been discussions in recent years that certain State governments, particularly those of a Liberal persuasion, would legislate to require voluntary student unionism in universities. If that were to happen, this Hawke-Keating-Dawkins Labor Government would get out the big stick and say, `We will take from a State's general revenue the exact amount that is required to make up the figure that would have totalled all students compulsorily being members of the union and paying the full union fees'. That is what the first part of clause 12 does. It says that such amounts are payable because the State has failed to fulfil a higher education funding condition.

The second part of clause 12 gives authority to the Treasurer, after the end of May of any year, to deduct from the payment due to the State under this Act any amount that is payable to the State and Commonwealth under paragraph (a); that is, to make up the money.

TALK.START.PARA: —It doesn't make it obligatory, though, does it?

—No, it does not make it entirely obligatory, but it provides a mechanism for the Commonwealth to recover the money. Of course, if there were was a Liberal or National Party government in office, as we fully expect in a couple of year's time, there would not be a compulsion upon a Liberal Treasurer to deduct that money. When the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Crean) introduced this Bill in the House of Representatives, he had this to say about clause 12:

SPEECH.PARA: A further change is the inclusion of a clause to complement amendments-presently before Parliament-to the Higher Education Funding Act-
then come words which are an entire joke-
to protect the rights and responsibilities of higher education institutions to make their own decisions, independent of Government interference . . .
I ask the Senate to ponder those words. It is crass hypocrisy. What is proposed in this Bill is, in fact, exactly the opposite of what Simon Crean said in that speech.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Crean.

—Mr Crean. It is exactly the opposite of what Mr Crean said. It is this Government interfering in the decisions of the students of universities in Australia by the big stick of funding mechanisms and pushing around States to make up the money that they may choose to allow students to pay voluntarily.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Acting Deputy President, you will know and all honourable senators will know that there is not one country in the world that has put in place such offensive legislation. Not one country requires compulsory unionism, not even in an industrial field, and not even as a trade union. Yet, here, this Labor Government is going beyond compulsory unionism in the industrial field to force the students of Australia to become members of an association.

Where is the choice? Where is the freedom of conscience? We are used to debates in this place against those matters that will undermine democracy in any country. We are opposed to any government forcing its citizens to become a member of a certain group. We believe that it is a principle that ought to undergird everything we do in this country; that there be freedom of association. It is just as important as freedom of speech.

Indeed, in the United Nations Charter and in all sorts of human rights summaries of principles, there is an affirmation of the right of freedom of association. This legislation tramples over that. It says that the students of Australia must become associated with a student union. We all know that student unions have several purposes. One is the admirable purpose of providing sporting facilities, dining facilities, places for students to meet in an extracurricular setting, places of fellowship, and places for societies to have rooms to enable students to come together.

The offensive aspect of any compulsion of students to be a part of an association is that there is a set of political activities that student associations engage in, and those political activities are often directly opposed by many students. Every year those students have taken steps to dissociate themselves from the political activities of a student association. It is offensive not only that a student be forced to be a member of an association but also that such associations pay moneys that can be used for political purposes against the conscience of those students. Mr Crean says that this legislation is:
. . . to protect the rights and responsibilities of higher education institutions to make their own decisions, independent of Government interference . . .

I charge him with exactly that offence and regard his statement as a joke. This Labor Government wants Parliament to legislate to restrict the freedom of choice for students when we should be legislating to enhance and entrench freedom of choice. This clause and the associated Bill supports compulsory unionism in every one of our higher education institutions. It goes to the length of using the Commonwealth's pre-eminent position in the funding of higher education to thwart any State government. But students should have a free and unfettered choice as to whether or not they join the student union at their institution; it is as simple as that. It is for that reason that the Opposition will totally oppose clause 12 and will vote against the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill when we debate it next week.

I might add that I listened carefully to Senator Spindler's reference in his speech this morning to his colleague Senator Bell's suggested amendment that would give an opting out provision for students. Certainly, the Opposition is very interested in that proposal, and we would like to see the precise words of Senator Bell's amendment. If it is as described by Senator Spindler in his speech this morning, we are very likely to support it. It is the case that we will be opposing the higher education funding legislation. It is the case that we are opposed to any compulsion not only in relation to membership of an association but also in regard to the payment of a student levy. But the opting out provision appears to meet at least some of the principles that we are advocating here now and will advocate next week in regard to that Bill.

I conclude by making just two points. Conscious of the propensity in our universities to have outspoken people-people prepared to speak out on principle-and conscious that there are many in our universities concerned about human rights and civil liberties, I am dumbfounded that we have not had scores of letters coming to us as members of parliament to protest this trespass upon human rights and the principle of freedom of association. I also refer to the institutionalised officers in each university for equal employment opportunity (EEO). Where are those EEO officers? Why have they not applied their minds to this Government compulsion? If they are taking very seriously the principle of equal employment opportunity, equal opportunities for students, fairness, non-discrimination and conscientiousness, where are their protests? Why are they not also putting their views to us in this Parliament and through the press to the public? I note that the education spokesman of the Opposition, David Kemp, has made similar--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Kemp.
—Dr Kemp.

— Professor Kemp, yes. He has made a similar point on this matter in the House of Representatives debate. My final point is to come back to a statement I made at the beginning. Mr Deputy President, you will understand this very clearly. Nowhere in the rest of the world is there legislation for compulsion of this kind. Why is it that Australia is the one country out?

SPEECH.PARA: Paradoxically the Labor Government wants this chamber to take this path at exactly the time the totalitarian dictatorships of the past 70 years, such as the Soviet Union and the countries of eastern Europe since the Second World War, are actually introducing choice and are opposing compulsion in their association and political arrangements. In the past 12 months we have seen the constitutions of the Soviet Union and other eastern European countries actually changed by their supreme soviets to deny a monopoly of power by the Communist Party in taking office or taking representative positions in those countries. The reason why that huge change has swept over eastern Europe is that those countries realise it is essential for political representatives to be freely chosen by the people so there can be a responsiveness from representatives to the people they represent and a dialogue between the representatives and the electorate.

One of the serious reasons for the failure of the communist system was the offensive compulsion over the past 70 years in the Soviet Union of people to vote only for Communist Party representatives. Just at the time when we see liberty breaking out in eastern Europe we find the Labor Government-totally contrary to the times and to the experience of all other countries in the world-placing compulsion on a student union. Simply put, the view of the Opposition is that students should be wooed, should be able to make a free choice and should see the benefits of being associated with a union and paying for membership of that union on the basis of the benefits which they assess will flow from that association.

I believe this legislation is disgraceful. It should be opposed not only by the Opposition but also by the Australian Democrats. I put it to Senator Spindler and the Democrats that in regard to this Bill-quite apart from the debate we will have next week when we may well agree on the amendment proposed by the Democrats-they should join the Opposition in throwing this clause out completely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like my colleague Senator Teague I also will confine my remarks to clause 12 of the States Grants (General Purposes) Bill 1990, which deals with the question of compulsory student unionism and indeed is complementary to the Higher Education Funding Amendment Act.

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments are designed to coerce the States into maintaining the current regime of compulsory student unionism, which the Opposition opposes. At present every Australian university student is forced to pay student union fees. The trade union slogan of `No ticket, no start' has been translated into a regime of `No union fee, no degree' by university administrations. Students are being threatened with expulsion due to their attempts to deny student unions of membership dues and others have been denied their university degrees due to their conscientious beliefs. This makes student unions among the most comprehensive and rigorous enforcers of the closed shop mentality in Australia.

There is no defence of civil liberties from university administrators. Universities seem to jealously guard their independence and their rights to free inquiry and free speech, but they are only too willing to compromise students' rights to free association. University vice-chancellors could perhaps be described as almost being the collectors for student unions by this compulsory requirement.

Effective representation requires that students have the ability to communicate their disapproval of an organisation by withdrawing their funding if they wish. This is denied them. Compulsory membership removes an essential channel of communication. If the membership were voluntary, we would see this mechanism work. Student unions become resource rich centres for those who control them and the scope for political activity is almost without limit.

In being forced to join student unions, students often find themselves involuntarily contributing funds for the promotion of causes with which they adamantly disagree. A litany of left wing groups have been propped up by student union fees over the years. Instead of providing a safety net to ensnare quality services, the compulsory union fee is the hammock, one could say, in which political activists luxuriate at the expense of students.

Before Liberal Party of Australia and National Party of Australia students won control of the University of Queensland Union, a women's rights librarian was paid a full time wage even though there were only 100 books in the collection. At Griffith University a `tree tax' was paid to conservation groups out of students' funds supposedly to compensate for trees cut down in the production of a student newspaper. The logic is mind-bending.

One could say that there are those who believe that feminist causes require public funding as distinct from those who believe they should do their own funding. On one campus a sum of $100,000 of students' fees was spent on feminist causes. Dr Gerard Henderson, Executive Director of the Sydney Institute, who first questioned compulsory student unionism 20 years ago, said:
Very often a small minority of left-wing political activists run student unions like a campus soviet-financially rewarding their mates and favourite political causes in the process.

There are plenty of examples to prove his statement is accurate. The effect of compulsory student unionism is best evidenced if one looks at what happens with the National Union of Students (NUS). NUS was formed in December 1987 and this year had an income from affiliated fees of close to $800,000. Approximately 80 per cent of NUS expenditure is directed towards wages and administration. The union has five fully paid student office bearers on a 12-member executive. That relates very well to Dr Henderson's statement. Membership of the NUS is compulsory for every student on campuses affiliated with the union so that individual students are not permitted to opt out of that union. The procedure prescribed by the NUS constitution renders disaffiliation at best difficult and in many cases practically impossible. Last year the union allocated $28,000 simply to campaign to get further affiliations and thereby more money in its coffers and more money for its mates.

TALK.START.PARA: —They did it in Western Australia and they bullied my little daughter at the university.

—That is outrageous. NUS purports to represent 250,000 students and yet less than 10 per cent of this figure actually voted to join the union. So much for freedom of expression on the campuses. There is no way NUS can claim to be representative of the majority of the students when campuses such as the Sydney University, the University of Queensland, the Australian National University and many other of the country's main campuses simply will not have a bar of it. By the introduction of this Bill and the associated amendments to the Higher Education Funding Amendment Act this Government becomes the shop steward for student unions right across the country.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me make one thing clear: I have no objection to students organising for common pursuit. Indeed, that is part of the activity of all students in universities. Student unionism becomes objectionable only when it is based upon compulsory membership and fees. It is objectionable for the very reason that compulsory trade unionism is objectionable-that is, being forced to join an organisation against one's will is a violation of the fundamental human right of freedom of association.

In fact, this is a simple issue of right and wrong. The question of right is the right of students to free association. The question of wrong is being forced to join a student union when one does not wish to so do. The main argument advanced in support of compulsory membership of student unions is that they provide for general student representation through compulsory membership. Therefore, there are no free riders because everybody is made to pay. It has been contended that if students did not have such an organisation their interests would suffer at the hands of parsimonious university administrations and governments. It could be argued that that is occurring now. If students feel that they have a need for student political representation, they will voluntarily associate in order to provide it.

Frankly, the union is little more than a campus extension of the Australian Labor Party (ALP). There is plenty of evidence on the record of that. At the 1987 NUS annual conference, it was resolved to spend $50,000 of students' money, compulsorily acquired, against the New South Wales coalition during the 1988 election because the then Opposition Leader, Nick Greiner, had promised to introduce voluntary student unionism. In other words, he was going to let people belong to a union if they wished and not be compulsorily required to do so-and $50,000 was spent on that.

During the last Federal election, the union devoted considerable resources to publications which were circulated across the country and which attacked the education policy of the coalition. This was in addition to a marginal seats campaign which also attacked the coalition. The union commissioned AGB: McNair Anderson to undertake a survey of student opinion prior to the election. We can draw our own conclusions as for what purpose this information was used.

Here we have the primary motivation for the Government's wish to maintain compulsory student unionism. Very simply, the Government sees it as an activity which is helpful to the ALP cause. Take away compulsion and taken away is a vital training ground for Labor Party activists; they might actually have to do it of their own volition.

From an economic point of view, compulsory union fees subsidise a range of service functions for student unions. These include cafeterias and refectories, bars, newsagents, theatres and gymnasiums. Of course, there are unsubsidised, off-campus alternatives to all of these services.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which are often used.

—Which are often used. But, of course, if a monopoly situation is provided on the campus, there is a lack of true competition between those who are genuinely in business and those who provide the service on campus. The result is that subsidisation allows student services to operate inefficiently, often running at a loss. Since membership is compulsory and due to the union's monopoly position, there is no discipline in prices or quality of service that ought properly to arise from competition.

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition's policy simply is that student unionism should and must be voluntary. Thus, we will be moving in the committee stage of this Bill an amendment in accordance with that belief. The case against compulsory student unionism is a compelling one. It goes to the very essence of the right to choose, the right to say how the money that one supplies is spent, the right not to be compelled to have one's money finance causes in which one not only does not believe but very often is absolutely opposed to. This is a serious issue, and that is why many of us are choosing to speak on it.

TALK.START.PARA: — I also rise to speak on the States Grants (General Purposes) Bill and to endorse the remarks of my colleagues, Senator Short, Senator Teague and Senator Bishop. I believe that this Bill contains one clause which, as my colleagues have stated, is particularly offensive not only to members of the Liberal and National parties but to all people who genuinely believe in civil liberties. As Senator Bishop has effectively outlined, clause 12 of the legislation is designed to buttress the pernicious practice of compulsory student unionism. It must be faced that compulsory unionism is a violation of freedom of association in this country. It is ironic that compulsory unionism has been allowed to develop throughout educational institutions which pride themselves in their rights to free speech, yet deny their students an equally important civil right-that of freedom of association.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Labor Party (ALP), to its undying shame, has played a leading role in denying tertiary students the right which so many other Australians enjoy. Above all, I think that this Government will go down in history as one that was noted for helping its mates, for granting special favours and for doing deals at the expense of principles which most people in this country strongly adhere to. One of the principles we are discussing today is the principle of freedom of association.

Clause 12 of this Bill is yet another attempt by a desperate government, and indeed a desperate and divided political party, to guarantee some sort of long term viability to its mates. It is an attempt to artificially perpetuate the existence of left wing student unions, many of which are members of the ALP.

Young people wishing to pursue further studies at tertiary institutions cannot do so without purchasing a union ticket. That is an absolute disgrace. Those who support compulsory unionism defensively claim that if a student is dissatisfied with a student union of which he or she is a member this student has the choice to become actively involved to reform such a union. Have the defenders of compulsory unionism forgotten that most students attend tertiary institutions to study and that many, quite properly, have no desire to spend vast amounts of time in student politics? They wish to spend more time on their studies. We give them credit for that.

Have student leaders forgotten that the way to empower-a word that the Left like to use a lot-students is to give students freedom of choice and allow students to truly express their own views. One of the best ways they can express those views is through the marketplace and through their willingness to join or not join a union. Tertiary students, by and large, are adults; they have the right to vote. Yet some people still wish to patronise these students by telling them that they are not capable of weighing up the costs and benefits of union membership and making a voluntary decision on whether to join a union or not.

Clause 12 of this Bill will ensure that States suffer a financial penalty if they legislate to end compulsory membership of student unions. This penalty will be the same loss to revenue as institutions will lose as a result of any change to voluntary student unionism. The States which choose, correctly, to go down this path of voluntary unionism amongst students would be penalised by losing many millions of dollars-sometimes tens of millions of dollars.

We are not opposed to unions; indeed, I have said in this chamber before that the more unions the better-provided, of course, they reflect the wishes of their members rather than the dictates of their officials. It is more than possible that voluntary student unionism would create more effective unions on many campuses. At last we would have student leaders whose success would be accurately measured by their ability to sign up members. Rather than face compulsion, students would join because they genuinely believed the union offered quality services and quality representation.

Under voluntary student unionism, student leaders can of course, if they so wish, spend vast sums of money on the very things that Senator Bishop has mentioned. They can spend money promoting the Palestine Liberation Organisation, the Australian Labor Party or, indeed, the Orange People, if they are still around. We are not preventing them from doing that but we are saying that they will have to convince their members that this money is well spent, that this spending of money reflects the priorities of their members, and if it does not they will suffer the ultimate sanction that all politicians suffer when they ignore their electorate-they will be chucked out of office; a principle which all of us in this chamber endorse. It is eminently predictable that a union leadership with a guaranteed source of income is likely to lose touch with mainstream membership concerns. Senator Bishop and Senator Campbell have pointed out to this chamber how out of touch in many areas the National Union of Students is.

Senator Spindler commented on the amendment that the coalition parties have moved. The Australian Democrats have a policy of voluntary unionism. Many in this chamber may not believe that, because we have to say that time and time again that is a policy which is more honoured in the breech rather than given effect to. The Democrats had a chance yesterday in relation to the Government proposal for mega-unions to again assert the right of voluntary unionism, and they did not do it. As we often see, when it comes down to making some hard decisions in relation to voluntary unionism regrettably they tend to support the Government. Today the Democrats have had another opportunity to bring Government legislation into line with their own policy. They could have done this by supporting the coalition's amendments.
The Democrats support the United Nations Declaration on Human Rights. They have told us that, and we believe them. Article 20 of that declaration states:
1. Everyone has the right to freedom of peaceful assembly and association.
2. No one may be compelled to belong to an association.

Senator McMullan is looking surprised by that, but that is one of the key rights in the Declaration of Human Rights, which, it has to be said, Senator McMullan's Party does not support. Is this not a time for the Democrats to support the policy as set out in their own policy documents? If the Democrats genuinely believe that no-one may be forced to join an association, they can effectively put that policy into effect by supporting the amendment to clause 12 of this Bill which Senator Short will be moving. They have said in this chamber that they will be supporting an amendment to the higher education funding legislation which will be coming before the Senate in the near future, to give students the right to opt out.

It is often suggested that conscientious objection is one way to safeguard the rights of those who do not wish to be members of a student union. Such clauses, however, are clearly inadequate in a number of ways. The basic human right embodied in the United Nations Declaration on Human Rights concerns itself with the initial freedom to join an association-this is otherwise known as opting in-as opposed to conscientious objection clauses, which supposedly allow students to opt out. We believe that conscientious objection clauses, while possibly better than nothing, do not fully safeguard the freedom of association.

From the outset it should be stated that student unions should earn their membership. The responsibility for the promotion of membership of student unions should clearly be the responsibility of those who run their organisations. Student unions are in many ways no different from other voluntary associations-sporting clubs, insurance companies and the like-and those organisations have to solicit membership. If the services they offer are attractive to a large group of people, such organisations survive. There exists no justifiable reason for a student union to subsist without the consent of those who provide the funds for its operation.
The Democrats had a chance to restore their credibility on the issue of voluntary unionism today. It is a great pity that once again they did not follow their stated principles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not retread the path that has been taken by my colleagues, who have in a very articulate way set out our objection to the profoundly obnoxious philosophy of compulsory unionism and the method used by the Government to impose it.

SPEECH.PARA: We are debating the States Grants (General Purposes) Bill of 1990, which gives effect to the arrangements agreed at the Premiers Conference and Loan Council meetings which took place on 28 and 29 June of this year. In general terms, general revenue grants for recurrent outlays will increase by 2.8 per cent in nominal terms, meaning a predictable fall of 3.7 per cent in real terms. Capital grants will remain constant in nominal terms, at $310.5m, and the Northern Territory is to receive $50m, while the borrowing limit for the six States for 1990-91 will total $3,800m with a per capita formula to be phased in over the next five years as the basis for allocating the global limit amongst the States and the Northern Territory.

There is a provisional commitment by the Commonwealth to maintain general revenue grants in real terms for three years, providing Australia does not experience any major economic deterioration-which of course is now thoroughly predictable. Of course, there is also clause 12, which has been debated thus far.

The Bill provides for an increase of 1.5 per cent in real terms for Commonwealth funding to the States. The States and local government account for 50 per cent of all government spending in Australia although they raise only about a quarter of all revenue directly. If this fact has any virtue, it is that it gives the Commonwealth control over fiscal policy. While the Commonwealth raises the bulk of government revenue, its funding to the States amounts to about 40 per cent of their revenue. It is interesting to compare that with 1980-81, for instance, when they provided 50 per cent of their revenue. This reduction has imposed a measure of restraint, superficially at least, on State spending and it has in some part allowed the Commonwealth to develop something of a public sector surplus.

There needs to be a reduction in special purpose grants and an increase in general purpose grants. It is interesting that general revenue grants have been cut by 2 per cent and specific purpose grants have increased by 4 per cent, notwithstanding the commitments given at the recent Premiers meeting in Brisbane. There needs to be a greater capacity for and by the States to raise their own revenue. The States have to be given access to other revenues they presently do not have. Some time ago the States were handed payroll tax-a most difficult and unpleasant tax. When Malcolm Fraser introduced his federalist policy, which allowed direct raising of taxes by the States, the States were very reluctant to take up that responsibility and take unto themselves the obligations that they have. It seems that the States are happy to accept and spend the revenue but not take the odium of raising it.

One of the other areas that must be looked at, and will be looked at by the next coalition government, is the question of duplication. The Senate can have all sorts of philosophical arguments about who is responsible for these various areas-whether education ought to be a State matter, a Commonwealth matter or a local government matter. At the end of the day, while that is philosophically important from a practical and economic point of view, it is important to sort out which tier of government is best able to manage it and which tier of government ought to be managing it.

If we look across the whole spectrum-education, roads, health, communications-we find that each tier of government has been dabbling, none particularly effectively, and adding enormously to the cost of administration. It is interesting to look at those States which are now in the best financial shape. For all the criticism that may have been directed at the Queensland Government, the Goss Government is now living on the responsible manner in which the Bjelke-Petersen Government balanced its books each year for 20 years.

Those States with the greatest financial difficulty, putting aside Tasmania, are Victoria and Western Australia. They have not governed themselves with proper restraint and responsibility. I will not canvass the question of clause 12, which I understand is going to cause us to be divided.
