I want to say something about that relativity and something about the implications of calls for enhanced fiscal restraint by the Federal Government.

On the question of relative fiscal restraint, the key question is: from what date do we start to measure these changes? In all measurements of trends and relative performances, the statistical validity of any comparison depends upon the validity of the starting point which is chosen. There are, of course, a myriad of those which could be chosen. Realistically, we all have to acknowledge that the fiscal restraint which all governments came to feel and which was sharply felt by Australians started in the fiscal year 1985-86 when external financial circumstances and particularly matters triggering a substantial decline in the value of the Australian dollar put great pressure on all levels of government for fiscal restraint. Spending cuts became the order of the day and that has been the overall fiscal atmosphere within which these matters have been debated in all the financial years since 1985-86.

Between 1985-86 and 1989-90-I choose that year only because it is the latest year for which up-to-date data on the States is available to us-the Commonwealth's own purpose general government outlays have fallen by around 2 per cent in real terms compared with an increase of around 5 per cent for the State and local government sector. Over the same period, the Commonwealth's revenue has increased by about 12 per cent in real terms compared with about 20 per cent for State and local own source revenue. I know those figures are not going to end the debate that has been going on for a long time, but I think it is important on each occasion to put those on the record.

I want briefly to refer to the other aspect of part (a) of the Opposition's second reading amendment: the failure of the Commonwealth Government to make sufficient cuts in its own purpose revenues. Those opposite cannot have a Tuesday economic policy and a Wednesday economic policy. Yesterday Senator Boswell was crying about the problems for small business-very real problems, very ineffectively advocated-but hundreds and thousands of small businesses will be very adversely affected by further substantial cuts in Commonwealth own purpose outlays because they provide services to the Government, they provide services to people who provide services to the Government, they provide services to the employees of the Government or-and all of them are in this category-they are dependent upon the level of economic growth in the economy. I will not duplicate any further the discussion which we had yesterday on the matter of public importance, but it is important to continue to recognise that in economics, as in other things, the whole equals the sum of the parts. If people keep advocating contradictory positions in different debates, the economic policy that ensues will not be coherent.

I will briefly say something about Senator Calvert's contribution. I acknowledge the genuineness of his concern about local government. Each time we talk about the important question of enhancing the capacity of the States to raise their own revenue to meet their own requirements, we have to be aware that we reduce the capacity of the Commonwealth to play a fiscal equalisation role because it does not have, to distribute to the States, the surplus with which that fiscal equalisation function can be performed. That is just a question of balance that we all have to acknowledge.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 12, page 8, clause to be opposed.

I think it has been made fairly clear from the contributions made in the second reading debate, particularly by my colleagues Senators Teague, Bishop and Kemp, as well as by me, that the Opposition is very strongly opposed to clause 12. Indeed, that was the reason why we divided on the second reading of this Bill.

The purpose of clause 12 as stated in the explanatory memorandum is to complement amendments currently before the Parliament to the Higher Education Funding Act 1988. The explanatory memorandum states:

The amendments to the Higher Education Funding Act are designed to impose on the States a requirement, as a condition of grants under that Act, not to prevent or hinder the imposition and collection of fees for organisations that represent the interest generally of students at an institution.

But what in effect clause 12 does is to entrench the practice of compulsory membership of student unions or, to put it perhaps more precisely, to seek to protect the capacity of tertiary institutions to force students to join a student union and pay the appropriate fee as a precondition of entry into the tertiary institution. It does that by having a provision to penalise any State which seeks to prevent tertiary institutions from undertaking what we regard very much as an obnoxious practice.

The Government, through this Bill, is in essence telling the States that, if they seek to protect the basic rights of students by ending the practice of coerced membership of student unions, they will suffer a financial penalty. The penalty they will suffer will equate with the revenue that the institutions will lose as a result of a change to the voluntary membership provisions of the student union. I think it is difficult to look at clause 12 as anything other than blatant blackmail of the States to enforce compulsory student unionism because, if they do not do so, they will be penalised financially. That is a form of coercion of the very strongest kind.

In his remarks, as I understood them, in summing up the second reading debate, Senator McMullan said that this was really a machinery clause at the end of a series of other actions of which the key actions are those contained in the Higher Education Funding Act. That is technically correct. Nevertheless, there are two points to be made on that. The first one is that it is very odd to be debating here a Bill which will have machinery provisions relating to another Bill which has not been debated in this chamber. Apart from anything else, the timing of consideration within the Senate of those two Bills seems to be wrongly juxtaposed. But that perhaps is not a matter for overly serious comment, although we do not know what the outcome of consideration of the Higher Education Funding Bill will be. As the Australian Democrats have said, the Bill may well finish up being a different Bill from what is now the Government's intention. So the juxtaposition is not a completely irrelevant matter by any means.

The other point to make in relation to Senator McMullan's comment that this is essentially a machinery provision in this States Grants (General Purposes) Bill is that it is a machinery provision of, as I said, a blatant blackmail nature because it will financially penalise States which have tertiary institutions which may have the courage and the foresight to go the route of voluntary unionism.

So I do not believe that clause 12 can be pushed under the carpet as purely a machinery type matter. It goes to a very fundamental matter indeed-a matter that my colleagues in the second reading debate put very eloquently and I believe very persuasively. I will not go over all their arguments again, other than to say that we believe that clause 12 of this Bill goes right to the heart of the basic principle of freedom of association.

For a student who does not wish to join a student union when enrolling in a tertiary institution, the practice of forced membership of the student union effectively means that that student will be forced to violate his or her deeply held political beliefs, or lack of political beliefs, as a precondition for enrolment. That violates the student's right to freedom of association and the equally fundamental right of freedom not to associate. That is what it is all about. Those rights of freedom of association or freedom not to associate are considered so important internationally and go to the whole core of our democracy. They are considered so important and integral to basic freedoms that they are in fact referred to in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. So we are talking about something of very considerable principle and magnitude indeed.

Any provision requiring compulsory membership of any organisation violates the basic liberal values for anyone to associate with any organisation or not to associate with any organisation. As soon as we start allowing into this Parliament an acceptance that we will pass laws which contravene the freedom of association or the freedom not to associate, we start going down the road of an antidemocratic state. So the basic principle involved in this of the right of freedom of association is fundamental to our approach to this clause 12 and, therefore, to the Bill.

There are other points to be made in relation to clause 12, apart from the principle involved. The fact is that the role of the States Grants (General Purposes) Bill traditionally has been to implement the decisions of the Premiers Conference. That is what this Bill is there for; that is its essential purpose. The issue of student unionism has nothing whatsoever to do with the Premiers Conference. It was not discussed at the Premiers Conference; it was not an issue at the Premiers Conference; no-one ever vaguely thought it had anything to do with the Premiers Conference, least of all the Premiers. So inclusion of clause 12 in this Bill clouds the very reason for the Bill's existence.

Another point is that clause 12 puts into a Bill dealing with general purpose payments-that is, untied, unconditional payments to the States-tied conditions because the payments to the States will be conditional on the tertiary institutions in those States acting in a certain way in relation to student unionism. So, again, it cuts across the whole conceptual thrust of the Bill.

The other thing that inclusion of clause 12 does in this Bill, because it does not relate at all to the main purpose of the Bill, is to invoke the piggybacking principle frequently adopted in countries, particularly by the United States Congress, of tying onto pieces of legislation provisions unrelated to that legislation in the hope that the piggyback bit will get through because the parliament wants to get the principal purpose of the Bill through.

I believe this is a form of legislative sleight of hand, of legislative blackmail. It is certainly quite contrary to all normally accepted parliamentary practice in Australia. Therefore, if we pass this Bill with clause 12 still included in it, I believe we will be setting a very dangerous legislative precedent indeed. If the Government wishes to pursue, for whatever reason, its wish to enforce and coerce compulsory student unionism, let it be honest and frank about it and do it in a legislative way not involving its being piggybacked through on something that is unrelated to it. There are other legislative processes available to the Government to attempt to get the concept of clause 12 through, if it wants to. It is absolutely wrong for it to be attempting to do so in this Bill.

They are the reasons, apart from the point of principle that I mentioned at the start, why I hope that the Democrats will-before we vote on this clause-have another look at their attitude to it, because it involves very important points of not only basic human rights principles but also, as I have said, basic legislative principles and practices.

I noted Senator Spindler's comments as to proposed amendments to the Higher Education Funding Bill that we will be debating next week. The amendments that the Democrats will be moving to that Bill next week, if I understood Senator Spindler correctly, do not really meet the concern that we have with the student unionism point because they will not enable a student to opt out of student unionism. Rather, they will allow them to opt out of paying that part of the student dues. If I am wrong on that-I see Senator Bell shaking his head-I will be interested to hear about it. But it will not affect our position on this Bill for all the other reasons that I have mentioned. I do hope that the Democrats will have another look at this because the Opposition believes that we will rue the day if we allow this clause to persist in this Bill because we will prostitute those fundamental principles. I commend the amendment.

—Well, I have circulated the amendment. My understanding is that it is common Senate practice to actually have the wording as we have circulated it, namely, that the clause be opposed. We are really saying that the clause be deleted, but in Senate parlance I am told that the clause be opposed is--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 12 in this Bill and the amendment moved by Senator Short on behalf of the Opposition raise two important issues. One of them relates to compulsory membership of organisations; I prefer to distinguish those from unions because, although the term student unions is used, I believe they should be distinguished from industrial unions which have a slightly different function. I believe it is a distinction worth making. Nevertheless, the principle remains that compulsory membership of organisations is something the Australian Democrats do not support.

SPEECH.PARA: The other factor that is raised by clause 12 is whether a national government, a Federal government, is entitled to use legislation that it introduces to promote national policies across the country, in a sense overriding States' rights. That raises the old debate of whether we are one nation or a conglomeration of States and it has to be decided on the merits of each particular issue as to whether it is a national policy and so desirable that the Federal government should press for all States to reach a similar stance and to obey similar laws. We have various degrees of cooperative arrangements. We have had them in corporate legislation. We have not had them in other areas where we perhaps would have been better off if we had had them, such as a national railway system. The Australian Democrats believe that a national tertiary education system and the principles that this provision seeks to promote are a worthwhile national objective.

I return, however, to the compulsory membership of associations. I contrast that negative with our belief that student participation in the governing of tertiary institutions should be promoted. We believe that people belonging to an organisation-in this case, students attending a tertiary institution-should have an effective say in the running of that institution. If students are not part of the student organisation which elects a students representative council which then, in turn, provides members to the governing body of the institution, that means that these students have not a base or a right to participate in the governing of the institution that they attend. There is, therefore, a case to be made for encouraging such participation. It is somewhat akin to saying to a person, `You have voting rights and you pay taxes in a country. You really cannot opt out because you should contribute and you should have the right to have a say in the decisions that are being made in the governance of that country. You can emigrate if you do not like it'. In a sense, that is the amendment that we will suggest and move to the subsequent Bill, the Higher Education Funding Bill, next week which my colleague Senator Bell will have carriage of for the Australian Democrats.

In answer to the question that Senator Short raised, it is our intention to provide in that amendment for the possibility for a student to opt out of membership of a student organisation, whatever it is called. We do not believe that that student should be allowed not to pay the service fees that go into providing the services that he or she would enjoy but we will seek to have a provision whereby those moneys are being paid for general services available to students rather than for political or semipolitical purposes to which that student may object.

I believe that this provision satisfies entirely the stance that we take in opposition to compulsory membership of associations. Quite clearly, an individual should be able to opt out. A citizen should be able to leave the country if he or she wishes to do so. But, at the same time, we believe that tertiary institutions will be better off if we have stronger student participation in those institutions. Subject to that qualification and amendment which, as I said, will be moved to the Higher Education Funding Bill when it is before the Senate, we do not support the deletion of clause 12 in the Bill which is now before the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Spindler for his comments, particularly the clarification he gave. Without wishing to prolong the debate, I just want to make two points. The question of enabling people to opt out of an organisation is, of course, totally different from the concept of their being free to join or not to join the association in the first place. What is being done is to provide a loophole, a way out, for people in relation to membership of an organisation, but to force them in the first instance to join that organisation. Therefore, the points that I was making in terms of freedom of association-the right to be free to associate or not to associate in the first instance-is not covered by that opting out procedure.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sorry that Senator Spindler did not address that fundamental principle as well as I would have hoped he would have done. I am sorry also that he has not addressed the other points of legislative practice and procedure and the precedents that the inclusion of clause 12 will set for future legislative possibilities and the whole obnoxious practice of piggybacking. Obviously, I am not going to be able to convince the Australian Democrats to change their minds. But I just want to record again my regret because I think that, by supporting the Government on this, they are being party to a very dangerous prostitution of the legislative procedures of this nation.

SPEECH.PARA: but the Senate:

I am not saying that on every occasion this should be opposed, but I am saying that it is an unfortunate precedent; I suppose it is a precedent when it is tied like this to a States Grants (General Purposes) Bill because normally, when the Commonwealth seeks to impose its will on the States, it must do so by reference to its constitutional powers. That is not doing things in a proper, constitutional fashion, relying on heads of power under the Constitution. I agree with what Senator Short says: this is just not a proper way of going about it. If the Government wants to do it, it should do it directly and do it by reference to a head of power under the Constitution. Surely, as such a principled individual, he would have done the same in Iraq, but I do not have one report back that he made the same sort of speeches in Iraq as he made here. I wonder what the reaction of his Iraqi hosts would have been to them. Did Mr Uren raise the question of one million casualties in the Iran-Iraq war and ask his hosts to justify their annihilation of Kuwait and the daily executions that are occurring there at present? The answer would have to be no.

The Government has taken a hard line on the principle of hostage taking, but it also expressed the hope that private envoys would be as successful as possible. We are particularly pleased that all foreign nationals now appear to be free to leave Iraq, and we do not think for a moment that this would have occurred without the resolute pressure applied by the whole civilised world.

I note that what Mr Uren has done has been to humiliate not only himself but also his country with his antics in Baghdad. I note his gratuitous advice when he goes on to criticise the new leadership of the Left for their so-called subservience and then worries about their place in history. Maybe some of that leadership of the Left will look back to the era when Mr Uren regularly briefed former Prime Minister Fraser on internal divisions within the Labor Party. That is something best forgotten on this side of the chamber.

Finally, I note from public reports before Mr Uren left for Iraq that his trip was paid for by local Arab Australians. What a pity a man of such great principle did not dip into his own vast superannuation payments and pay his own way.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Prime Minister to the Prime Minister's statement in his press conference yesterday that he had been approached by a range of people within the parliamentary party and outside it, which led to his decision to change his mind about how long he was going to remain in politics. —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I refer to the recent wool marketing mission to the major buying countries led by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, John Kerin. As a result of the trade talks, can the Minister advise the Senate of the short, medium and long term forecasts for the Australian wool producing industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The outcomes of the mission that John Kerin led overseas to promote Australian wool look more promising than was anticipated before he left. Some say the success of the trip is being reflected in the rise in trade buying at wool sales in recent days. This is possibly a bit simplistic. However, the wool mission did significantly reduce the fear of massive inventory losses if our customers return to the auctions in some strength. Confidence is the key in bringing them back into the market and the wool mission was crucial in that respect.

ANSWER.PARA: In all major buying countries, uncertainty in the marketplace has brought pipeline stocks down to an absolute minimum. Buying for immediate processing for retail sale in the 1991-92 Northern Hemisphere autumn-winter will occur over the December and January sales. So far in December we have seen a good pick up in demand with a Corporation buy-in rate falling to around 50 per cent.

Final retail demand remains strong in Japan, Germany, Korea and Italy; moderate in France and weaker in the United Kingdom. Demand in the Soviet Union is also strong at all stages of the pipeline. However, the economic problems of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics have left it without the foreign exchange to purchase stocks. We are confident that the $400m credit facility we put in place will kick-start the Russian trade and we will see it active in the market in the near future. There are clear signs that Japan will play a bigger role in the market next year. China, which has its own stockpile of wool and a depressed internal and external retail demand, will be slower to resume buying on a large scale, but I expect its purchases will steadily increase.

The short answer to Senator Foreman's question is that the prospects for increased export sales of Australian wool are brighter than at perhaps any other time over the last 12 months. However, we must wait and see whether these prospects turn into reality before we can claim that they are ultimately successful. However, any improvement cannot come too early. Even if the present improvement is maintained, the wool industry in Australia is still facing difficult times and hard decisions as it is forced to manage the current oversupply situation and the massive stock overhang that will, unfortunately, be around for some seasons to come.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. Is the Minister aware that last month there was an unprecedented 85 per cent increase in the number of people calling on the Salvation Army in Adelaide for assistance with food? Is the Minister aware that in the first two weeks of December this year there has been a 46 per cent increase in demand for assistance from St Vincent de Paul compared with the same two weeks last year? Is the Minister aware that, as I speak, some South Australian welfare agencies are having to turn away needy families because the agencies have had their resources exhausted as demand is increasing so, unfortunately, donations of goods are decreasing? Finally, I ask the Minister: as the Treasurer has taken some pride in claiming the recession as his own creation, does the Government have any plans to provide additional financial support to the welfare agencies so they can cope with its human consequences?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Welfare agencies have been around for a long time. They preceded the recession. They have seen many other recessions. They do a phenomenal job in distributing voluntary aid to those in need. The Commonwealth, as far as I am aware, has not been involved in cash handouts to those agencies, and they do not knock on the door seeking them either. I do note in press reports in the last few days that St Vincent de Paul has claimed that its contributions are down 30 per cent and yet it has had a very big increase in those who are calling upon its resources. I was not aware of any figures from South Australia. I do have a number of articles here, but I have not seen one from South Australia just yet.

ANSWER.PARA: I will certainly take Senator Lees's word for the fact that one cannot have a recession without more people out of work, and when more people go out of work undoubtedly the strain on charities will become very much greater. The Government will continue to provide a welfare safety net which, in my view, is second to none. It will, however, not satisfy those who are going out of work. Obviously, it will mean the tightening of belts for very many Australian families over Christmas. No-one on the Government side would have wanted that. Having said that, either we take tough decisions now or we hand these problems to the next generation. I would like to think that, after all of us in this Parliament leave parliamentary service, we will have sought to minimise the problems that we hand down to the next generation. That is what the decisions that the Government has taken will undoubtedly do.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I just wish to emphasise that we are talking about those people who are falling through the welfare net. I ask the Minister: as a result of what he has just said, is he suggesting that, if the Salvation Army and the St Vincent de Paul Society seek assistance, the Government would be able to provide them with some at this point in time?

—No, I have not indicated that we would be providing them with assistance. That has been a matter mostly for voluntary aid and sometimes for State governments. It is not on the program at the present time for us to do so. I simply made the point that those organisations had not approached us. I understand that people fall through the welfare net. However, they fall through the net for matters of days, not for months. The welfare net is there for the obvious purpose of picking them up and does so. Some who fall through the net do so because they do not pass relative tests. They do not pass relative tests often because of the amounts they have in the bank. We have recently had some quite surprising cases reported to us of people coming in wanting to get on relief and yet having quite extraordinary sums of money in the bank. For most people that is not the case. Most are struggling. But if they are struggling they do not fall through the net, because the income and assets tests that they go through are set at such levels that anyone who is genuinely in need will pass.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. I preface my question by saying that the Minister will be aware of the rapid increase on supermarket shelves lately of products that are claimed to be environmentally friendly. Can the Minister tell the Senate what the Government is doing to ensure that consumers are able to make environmentally safe purchases?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator West has been observant in noticing that many manufacturers and suppliers do attach some sort of environmental friendly logo to their products on supermarket shelves and elsewhere in an attempt to make claims about the way in which those particular goods have a beneficial impact on the environment. I believe there is a growing confusion in the marketplace about the proliferation of such labels and, indeed, I think they can be misleading.

ANSWER.PARA: There is a danger that some schemes which have been suggested, such as a green spot scheme and so on, can be too crude and simplistic and do not take into account all the factors needed to determine whether or not a particular product being purchased has a severely detrimental impact on the environment. For example, one has to take into account such factors as the mode of production, of manufacture, of the particular good, or perhaps the way in which it was harvested, grown or produced. Also, one has to look at the packaging in which the particular item is sold, and the way in which that packaging can be disposed of.

It is this cradle to grave approach which certainly cannot be comprehended in some simple green spot labelling scheme. For that reason, both in my case and in that of Mrs Kelly, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, there has been a concern that one looks to the wider issues of education of consumers and of manufacturers and retailers to enable a more sophisticated approach to satisfying the legitimate requirement and desire of those who are purchasing goods to, as far as possible, avoid making purchases which contribute to a detrimental impact on the environment.

To that end Mrs Kelly organised a round table conference a couple of days ago in Canberra with industry leaders, government planners and consumer and environmental groups. I believe that some more practical proposals in this regard will emerge from that round table conference. It is important to note that protection against false or misleading environmental claims already exists under the Commonwealth Trade Practices Act and the fair trading Acts in the various States with, I believe, penalties for making misleading claims including fines of up $20,000 for individuals and $100,000 for corporations. A structure is in place and can be invoked to deal with those cases where blatantly misleading advertising of a product as environmentally friendly takes place. If it is deceptive and misleading, it ought to be dealt with in terms of that legislation. Indeed, the Trade Practices Commission only last Friday put out draft guidelines dealing with that particular matter, which can be responded to shortly.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many were tabled?

—As Senator Hill is taking a tremendous interest in this, I simply make the final point-and he would agree, I am sure-that consumers want to make decisions in regard to their purchases which are for the good of the environment. We are doing everything we can to help ensure that that choice can be made with as much information as possible, but not in a simplistic or crude way. I think it is worth taking some time over that to ensure that we get the balance right in the information provided to consumers.
—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. Can the Minister advise the Senate of the circumstances surrounding the rescue of five persons from the ketch Mariana off Darwin in the early hours of this morning and of whether an emergency position indicating radio beacon (EPIRB) contributed to their rescue.
—Were they constituents of yours?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to that interjection, not only were they constituents of mine; in fact, they were friends of mine. I was extremely anxious last night about their safety. Fortunately, thank goodness, they were rescued as a result of actions taken by the Civil Aviation Authority, the Sea Safety Centre and, I understand, the Royal Australian Navy, at 4 o'clock this morning.

ANSWER.PARA: The question is a very timely one because, as honourable senators would recall, in recent times I have mentioned just how successful the new satellite based rescue system has been. In fact, since it was commissioned in October last year, it has been responsible for saving in excess of 70 lives. The question is particularly important because the search yesterday was badly hampered by the fact that this particular vessel, which had, as well as four adults, a small child on board, in the middle of a cyclone was not carrying an EPIRB.

TALK.START.PARA: —You had better get your mind back on WIRA.

—This is in fact a serious question. The fact is that this equipment costs just a little in excess of $200. I have stressed again and again in the Senate in recent times the importance of the equipment. Again I urge people going to sea to spend $200 on this equipment.

ANSWER.PARA: I conclude by saying that there is another reason why they should do so. The search conditions again were highly hazardous yesterday for the searchers. It is not stretching the point to say that the people who searched for that vessel risked their lives in doing so. Regrettably, they were forced to spend a much longer time in the search area under very hazardous conditions because the vessel did not have an EPIRB and they were forced to try to track it down by the old method of positioning themselves on the radio signals from the vessel.

Had the EPIRB been carried, they would have been able to go immediately to the location of the vessel, and the rescue could have been effected some hours earlier, taking the searchers out of a very dangerous and hazardous area. I take this opportunity to stress once again to all mariners that they should spend the $200. The installation of satellite compatible EPIRBs by mariners before they go to sea is a very small investment in terms of preserving life.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Does the Minister agree with Richard Solomon, United States Assistant Secretary of State for East Asia and Pacific Affairs, that there is a `significant possibility' that the communist Khmer Rouge could win on the battlefield, and that Hun Sen is now losing credibility within his own power structure as well as the general Cambodian populace?

—I answered this question in some detail in the statement I made last week. There is a possibility in the longer term of such an outcome if the Khmer Rouge continue to be supplied externally, as they have been for so long, and if there should be a significant deterioration, indeed collapse, in the morale, discipline and performance of the Phnom Penh Government. Such a collapse is not imminent in our judgment, but it is something that could occur in the longer term. The need for a settlement remains as urgent as it always has been. In fact, I stand by the judgment that unless such a settlement along the lines that have been proposed--
—This is another disaster area you are involved in.
—This was the danger of bringing the KR into a settlement, wasn't it?
—Senator Alston, you are consistently interjecting and I ask you to cease.

—This series of interjections demonstrates a combination of ignorance and arrogance as well as indifference to the fate of the people of Cambodia which is nothing short of contemptible. As for the vulgar and contemptible populism that Senator Hill has succumbed to in his purported role as foreign ministerial spokesman for his Party, I have nothing but contempt for it and for everything he has stood for and expressed in recent weeks on the subject. We are trying our guts out to resolve the tragedy of the Cambodian people. We are not prepared to make compromises with vulgar populists who crow crowd-pleasing emotional propositions which have no substance and no credibility and which have no intelligence backing behind them, or indeed any intelligence behind them. The stance that we have adopted, the path that we have crafted and which we have been trying to implement diplomatically over the last year, is the only way out of the impasse of the tragedy for the Cambodian people. It is about time that people in the Opposition realised that.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister: to the extent that the Minister does accept the view I noted, is there not a danger that the Australian initiative is locking in a revised power balance which could see the return to power of the murderous Khmer Rouge?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no danger of that occurring. Senator Teague ought to appreciate, if he knows anything about what the proposal was and how it was proposed to be implemented, that that is so. The simple truth of the matter is that the Australian proposal, as now endorsed not only by the Permanent Five but by the entire United Nations at least through the Security Council and now the UN General Assembly, is a proposal which was built around the concept of a transitional period in Cambodia which will involve a UN peacekeeping presence, a UN organised election and a UN supervised civil administration to ensure a level playing field, and there is no better guarantee that I can think of that a fair outcome will result. If at the end of that particular process it is the case that the Khmer Rouge chooses not to accept the results of a ballot so conducted but to go on fighting, which is something we have always acknowledged to be a possibility, it will be doing so, by definition in the context of this settlement, in an environment where it is no longer being supplied by any external country-including, in particular, China, which has armed and kept the Khmer Rouge going-and as such has the eminently likely prospect of being marginalised and isolated within a comparatively short period of time. That marginalisation and isolation is utterly unlikely to occur in the absence of such a settlement and in the absence of the withdrawal of external support.

ANSWER.PARA: That is the essence of the Australian plan, the UN plan, and that is why this plan has been understood and accepted internationally, worldwide, as the only way of guaranteeing a peaceful long term outcome for the tragedy of Cambodia. I despair of the lack of sense and intelligence, goodwill, and commitment to peace of the Opposition when, through the mouths of this babbling buffoon here at the front and Senator Teague at the back, for crude and populist reasons they keep on producing propositions of the kind they are putting forward in Question Time today. They are simply not committed in good faith to a resolution of this problem. They are committed to grandstanding, they are committed to doing anything that will win them cheap applause from people who do not deserve to be taken seriously.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on a point of order: the Minister has reflected upon the genuineness of the Opposition in putting views. Why would the Minister put depredations upon us of lacking in morality or good intentions? Surely, it is against the Standing Orders for the Minister to make those inferences about members of the Opposition.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is it true that the Confederation of Australian Industry (CAI) survey on the training needs of managers shows that middle level managers and supervisors in Australia feel they need more specific and practical industrial relations training? Will the provision of more and better training to managers and supervisors equip them better for the demands of today's industrial relations environment? How is the Federal Government responding to the needs identified in the report?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the first two questions is yes and yes. To the third question, I can tell the Senate that today I launched a survey conducted by the Confederation of Australian Industry which demonstrates the increasing need for managers to be trained in practical, up-to-date industrial relations skills. The survey on training needs of managers shows that today's supervisors have clearly assumed responsibilities for day-to-day industrial relations functions. Eighty-six per cent of supervisors have to deal with industrial relations issues on a regular basis; 90 per cent of companies use supervisors to brief their work force on matters affecting them; and yet 91 per cent of supervisors learn their industrial relations skills on the job or try to pick them up as they go.

ANSWER.PARA: Management at all levels needs to keep pace with changes being made in industrial relations at both industry and enterprise levels. Only by having the knowledge with which management will need to be equipped will it grasp new opportunities and challenges available under the structural efficiency principles. The report which was released today to the National Labour Consultative Council by the Confederation of Australian Industry was funded by the Commonwealth and identifies that the industrial relations training needs of managers at different levels in both large and small enterprises are critical and must be increased.

The report identifies that one of the biggest blockages to structural reform in the workplace is the lack of skills, in particular, of middle management. In responding to this need, I announced today a new component of the national workplace reform program entitled `Management Training and Industrial Relations'. We have developed this program as a significant initiative with the Confederation and will begin to address many of the issues raised in the report.

I have approved Federal Government funding of $400,000 to allow the Confederation of Australian Industry to develop suitable training packages based on the `working together' package developed jointly by the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), the Confederation and my Department. The presentation of these courses will be coordinated by the Confederation of Australian Industry across all States through Confederation affiliates and other interested organisations. It is intended that 6,000 managers and supervisors around Australia will be trained in the first six months of 1991. I believe that significant demand will be generated by this initiative. Industry bodies and individual enterprises will be encouraged to accept the challenge to provide a significant upgrading of training at management levels. Work will also commence on compiling a register of suitable industrial relations courses in line with the report's recommendations.

The theme for the 1990s in industrial relations will be workplace change. This will ensure in part that one of the partners in the workplace-middle management-is trained to meet that challenge and implement the program of productivity and profitability improvement that this Government supports with the ACTU and the CAI.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McLean says there were some 1,500 veterans and members of their families at the rally at the Town Hall last Monday. My information is that there were about 800 people there. Some 15,000 were treated at Concord. All of these veterans will benefit from the proposed private patients scheme and the integration process. The fact that 25,000 veterans were treated so well and in such a satisfactory way in the public hospital system in New South Wales indicates, no doubt, that they wanted to be closer to their families and friends in the local community and more adjacent to their normal place of residence.

—She is all right when she is before a rally with people that she--

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AWARD BREACHES: ARRANGEMENTS BETWEEN EMPLOYERS AND EMPLOYEES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Where employers and employees agree to temporarily working shorter hours than allowed for under the award in order to maintain jobs in this recession the Government says we needed to have, what steps will the Minister take to ensure that employers do not face prosecution for breach of the award provisions as they did in the last recession?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to that question is, none. In fact, if an employer wishes to breach an award he should be prosecuted for that breach of the award. That is the simple law. What the honourable senator is asking is that the Government should not enforce the law. I ask her to consider her responsibility, as a senator in this place, and the implications of requesting a government not to enforce the law. So the answer to her question is, no.

ANSWER.PARA: The implication of her question is that in times of economic slowdown there may be an agreement in a workplace to change the working arrangements in order that more people will be retained in employment. The answer to that part of the question is that there are procedures to be followed to see that an arrangement is consistent with industrial relations principles and not one in which workers are told by employers, `agree or you are sacked'-therefore, an employee has no choice; it is not a bargain between equals but a bargain between a dominant group able to victimise a group that is not dominant.

If the proper procedures are followed, there are provisions within the Industrial Relations Act which enable award flexibility clauses to be negotiated and approved of by the umpire, the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, to guarantee that they are fair and approved of in such a way that the award can then be varied.

My very firm advice to employers who may be contemplating opening negotiations of the sort that the honourable senator's question implies may occur, is that they take care to see that they conform with the proper procedures under the Act. Otherwise, they will be contracting out of their lawful responsibility and inducing others to do so as well, and that is a clear breach.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Could the Minister indicate how long the procedures he referred to take to be completely satisfied? In the event of employers and employees coming to an agreement, can they put that agreement into operation prior to those procedures being concluded or will the employers be prosecuted for a technical breach prior to the formalities being completed? How long will those formalities take?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am being invited to answer a question to which it is impossible to give an answer. The reason why the question is impossible to answer is that it does depend on the nature of the agreement. I cannot foreshadow what each agreement might be. If I could, I would answer the question. If the agreement has been properly negotiated and the union representing workers in the workplace has been involved then, by consent, it would go through the proceedings of the Industrial Relations Commission speedily. If the agreement has not been negotiated and the union which is the representative of the workers in the workplace is not involved, if it is an attempt to bypass the union and divert the proceedings away from the Commission, and if it is an agreement which is unfair and is contested, then it may take a lot longer. This raises another question: if an employer is proposing or wanting to enter into an agreement of this sort, the employer is best advised to give as much notice as possible to enable proper and full consultation with the work force involved and the unions concerned so that--
—While jobs go down the drain?

—No. So that the procedures can be followed. The honourable senator refers to the words `technical breach'. I would like to know where under any law the defence can be, `We technically breached the law, but we ought not be penalised'. This is the law. I believe that the honourable senator in her private life is a solicitor. She would know, according to that, that a person either breaks the law or does not, and a person cannot take the defence that this was a technical breach.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me go to another matter which touches on exactly this sort of issue and which is an important matter in terms of balance, equity and fairness. In the years 1985, 1986, 1987 and 1988, the economy in this country was growing strongly. Employment was burgeoning; the bargaining shares that might normally obtain in industrial relations were firmly on the side of the unions and balanced against employers. At that time, when unions could have exploited the economic cycle to their benefit, we got moderate outcomes on wages, and the Opposition lambasted the Government at the polls, saying that we had reduced real wages. We had, but we had increased real household disposable income per capita. The Opposition did not tell that truth. But real wages fell at a time in which unions could have pressed their claims.

Now that the economic cycle is flatter and the bargaining shares are on the side of the employers, I would like to see employers in this country exercise the same discipline and responsibility to the national economy that unions did during the time in which the bargaining shares stood in their favour. I would like to see them do it in a way in which they involve their work forces in effecting the workplace reform programs capable of being achieved under award restructuring- something that this Government has introduced with the support of the Confederation of Australian Industry and of the Australian Council of Trade Unions to make workplaces more efficient and more productive. That is the way to weather the terms of the recession, not by victimising people and saying, `Out the gate if you don't agree'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Is the Minister aware of an editorial in Monday's Australian Financial Review which states that there are not enough opportunities for science graduates in this country? Given the jobs that are created by industry using the results of scientific research in Australia, what is the Government doing to encourage greater levels of commercialisation of the research carried out in our great public institutions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the article. I hope that more science students and teachers read it. There are too few employment opportunities for science graduates in industry because industry has been slow to recognise the benefits of research. We have had a clear policy, however, of encouraging research com- mercialisation, and a number of schemes such as the national teaching company scheme, which has been very well regarded, have been put in place for that purpose, as has the national procurement development program.

ANSWER.PARA: We have also had the tax concession for research and development and incentives to help the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) and industry collaborate further. Today my colleague Simon Crean is launching the Latrobe University Research and Development Park, which will be an important addition to the R and D infrastructure in the outer suburbs of Melbourne. CRA Ltd will be the first advanced technology development unit company to take up work in that park.

I should also add that, in spite of many rumours or stories to the contrary, we have had a significant net gain by the migration of technically qualified scientists and engineers in the last few years. In current circumstances, that pool of talent has added to the significant number of Australian trained scientists and engineers already here. The article makes some good points but it has to be seen in that context and with a degree of balance.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the Minister to the article in the Australian Financial Review on Monday 10 December headed, `Early company tax payment plan ill-timed', which detailed the fact that most companies will be paying all of their 1989-90 tax next Monday, with 85 per cent of 1990-91 liability due next July. Thus, nearly two years of tax payments will fall due within seven months. I ask the Minister: considering the low level of Christmas activity, reduced cash flow in January and holiday pay payments, what consideration has the Government given to the call by the chief of the Australian Chamber of Commerce, Ian Fletcher, to defer next Monday's payments to at least the end of February?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have a precise answer on that question at the moment but I will try to get one for Senator Panizza as quickly as possible. I recall the newspaper comments and other representations that have been made about this issue. However, I should say that it is not an issue about which companies have been unwarned.
—They weren't about the recession either.

—No. We had this debate here at the time of the introduction of the relevant legislation following the Budget. Although there was a lot of discussion about those issues at the time, I think honourable senators will recall that Australia, in making those changes, was bringing our tax legislation into line with legislation of a similar kind in the majority of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) countries.
—Why don't you bring the economy into line?

—Senator Walters asks why we do not bring the economy into line. I remember this interjection; I have had it from Senator Walters for years. It used to be: why do we not bring the economy into line with that of Great Britain? That used to be Senator Walters's interjection, but she is like one of those lizards that drops its tail when it gets worried. Senator Walters has dropped the tail end of her question because it is no longer relevant. Margaret Thatcher is no longer there; Britain has double digit inflation, a very severe economic situation and wages rising at something closer to 20 per cent than 10 per cent; and we do not have these comparisons any more.

ANSWER.PARA: The point about the tax structure, which Senator Panizza asked me about-a more serious question than that involved in Senator Walters's interjection-is an important point and I will try, as I said, to get him an answer as soon as possible.

QUESTION.PARA: If such a crisis were to occur again the Government would need to give closer consideration to special support arrangements for the industry.

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised that Mr Kerin has responded by saying that the accelerated payment option has been a matter considered by the Government previously. Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
KERIN MEETS WITH GRAINS COUNCIL OF AUSTRALIA
The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, John Kerin, met today with leaders of the Grains Council of Australia (GCA) to discuss problems facing many of Australia's wheat growers.
Whilst domestic demand for hard and prime hard wheat is strong, pool returns for ASW and lower grades of wheat, which comprise around 80% of the production, are lower than expected.

``Returns to Australian growers have been destabilised by the absurd levels of subsidies being paid overseas particularly by the US and EC. As well, the Gulf crisis has created substantial marketing problems for the current season's crop,'' Mr Kerin said.

``The Government took both these matters into account when it agreed a few weeks ago to increase the National Interest cover for this season's crop which included the $125m credit facility for purchase of wheat by the USSR.''

``I will be monitoring very closely the wheat situation over the next few weeks in the lead up to the Post Harvest payment in March 1991 but it is still too early to predict the impact of international events on those payment decisions,'' Mr Kerin said.

Mr Kerin said that he was meeting with State Ministers responsible for the Rural Adjustment Scheme tomorrow. Ministers would be discussing the review of the Scheme and Mr Kerin would also raise with them the wheat situation and assistance facilities under the Scheme.

DEBATE.TITLE: REPATRIATION COMMISSION AND THE DEPARTMENT OF VETERANS' AFFAIRS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the documents.

It is a mammoth undertaking to consider in five minutes the reports of the Repatriation Commission and the Department of Veterans' Affairs and obviously quite impossible: they are huge documents. There are, however, two matters which have been of particular concern to the veterans' community referred to in those reports, which I should like to address very briefly.

The annual report under the heading of `Major Achievements', outlines the review it undertook of the second edition of the Guide to the Assessment of Rates of Veterans' Pensions, also known as GARP II, and the recommendations flowing from it. These recommendations have led to the creation of GARP III, which was recently tabled in the Senate. In the eyes of the ex-service community, this has been far from a major achievement, as claimed by the annual report. GARP III has effectively excluded any consideration of lifestyle effects in the determination of the rate of disability pension payable to a veteran.

The Government has abolished the lifestyle report, which has been the subject of much criticism by veterans, from GARP II. However, in doing so it has removed any concession to the impact on lifestyle which a disability may cause to different veterans.

Recognising the obvious problems associated with GARP III, I have given notice that I will disallow it unless the Government and the ex-service organisations can come to a satisfactory agreement on a revised version or an alternative. We hope that the Government properly addresses its responsibility on this matter and that the interest of the veterans' community is paramount-not only the convenience of the Department and the efficiency of the system.

The second aspect associated with the annual report which I would like to comment on concerns the proposed transfer of the repatriation general hospitals to the States. The Government has yet to satisfy major concerns with the integration raised by the ex-service organisations and the States. These are proper concerns and relate to the priority of access, the quality of care, the funding arrangements and the timetable proposed.

It has often been mentioned in this place that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) promised, back in April 1989 before there was an election, that no repatriation hospital would be transferred to a State unless these concerns I have mentioned had been satisfactorily addressed. Since that time, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) has been telling the veterans' organisations that it does not matter how much they object, integration is proceeding and it will be impossible to wind back by the next election. Of course, that steamrolling effect has simply stiffened the resolve of the veterans' organisations-and also, of course, the Opposition-which believe that the Prime Minister must be made to honour his promise.

As a result of the war veterans rally which was held in Sydney early this week, I think the Government is coming to recognise that it cannot continue blindly to push ahead with integration when there are so many unresolved issues that have not been dealt with. There were hundreds and hundreds of veterans at that turnout in the Sydney Town Hall this week, and Minister Tate tried to belittle that rally. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs seemed to be changing his tune there because instead of saying, `It does not matter how much one screams and yells, it is going to happen, we are committed to it and it will all be in place by the next election', he simply said that it will not take place unless, firstly, all reasonable concerns of the Returned Services League and other veterans' organisations are resolved; secondly, unions have reached a satisfactory agreement with the Government; and, thirdly, Federal and State governments can agree on the terms and conditions associated with the proposed transfer.

I was glad to hear the Minister starting to change his tune. However, I hope that was not simply to quieten down a very heated meeting. I hope that he and the Prime Minister will stick to those promises. It was sensible of the Minister to change his tune because there is no hope of getting his own way with a gun at the head of the veterans' organisations-which is the way he has been going on this year. Both the questions of GARP III and the integration of the hospitals can only be dealt with on the basis of the benefit for the veterans. For the sake of the veterans they have to have considered and informed discussion.

The Government's failure to get projections on the expected usage of the private hospitals, the public hospitals or the repatriation hospitals in an integration process is a matter of concern. Equally worrying is the fact that the Senate has been told by Senator Tate that the Government does not even know what such a scheme would cost; whether it would be more expensive or less expensive than the existing one. It simply took a policy decision with no information at all. That is no way to govern this country, especially when it comes to governing for a veterans' population which is elderly and needs stability, certainty and care. We do owe a debt to the men and women who fought for this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly to this report. Essentially, I will be reinforcing and supporting the statements just made by Senator Newman. These reports attempt to put a good face on what in fact is a less than adequate situation for veterans in this country. Veterans are becoming much more politicised and aggressive in expression of their dissatisfaction about the Government's attitude towards them.

SPEECH.PARA: Certainly an ongoing source of dissatisfaction to veterans has been the Guide to the Assessment of Rates of Veterans' Pensions or the method of assessing their disability, which has been put alongside this intrusive lifestyles questionnaire which they have resented for so long. It is a running sore. It is something that the Government has to address and resolve in the best interests of veterans' needs. There is no doubt that they feel strongly on this issue. They are not satisfied with the prevailing set of circumstances.

I give notice that the Australian Democrats will be supporting Senator Newman's disallowance motion on Thursday of next week. We have had extensive discussion with veterans' peak organisations and also with officers of the Department of Veterans' Affairs, explaining why we will be supporting the disallowance. We will be attempting to make a positive contribution and a positive range of suggestions to the Department and to the Government whilst at the same time putting things on a temporary hold-it might be quite a temporary hold-in the hope that this ongoing area of dissatisfaction can finally be resolved.

I would like to refer briefly to Senator Tate's response to my questions earlier in Question Time, which, in fact, related to the rally at Sydney lower Town Hall on Monday. I was not there. I have been to the last two rallies in the lower Town Hall. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) has not been to the last two. He was there on Monday. I will accept the fact, perhaps on hearsay, from many of the people who have contacted me that he was received in a very angry and aggressive manner by a veterans' constituency which is increasingly disillusioned.

The subject of that rally was the question of the amalgamation of repatriation hospitals or their absorption into the general hospital system. Senator Tate has stood in this place over and over again in response to questions from me and reiterated the empty assurances that the Minister and the Government have given, and gave yet again on Monday, to veterans that this transition will be smooth and there will be no lack of provision, yet at the same meeting we have got a State Minister standing up and saying if that is going to occur the cost is going to be $150m each year, year after year, or alternatively, the private hospital system is going to have to absorb the impact. The private hospital system is not capable of absorbing it, and nor is the public hospital system.

I think that the Government has done two things here. As Senator Newman rightly said in closing her remarks, it has failed to do the homework. It has not analysed the implications of this speeded transition. It has not anticipated the reaction of State health Ministers in saying they will not wear the cost of it. It has not adequately sampled the opinion of veterans as to whether they want it to go that way. Some do, but many do not. Therein lies the rub.

It has not attempted, nor did Senator Tate attempt today, to address the enormity of the costs of the private hospital sector having to pick up the servicing of veterans' needs. Frankly, I think there is a whole range of unanswered questions within the administration of this Department which are not adequately acknowledged in this report, which puts a good face on the servicing and administration of the Department, and which is in fact confronted with a very dissatisfied constituency. The Government is simply not accepting the realities of the degree and the nature of that dissatisfaction amongst the veteran community.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to note briefly that the Opposition certainly endorses the adoption by the Resource Assessment Commission of an integrated approach to both conservation-which includes all environmental and ecological considerations-and development aspects at an early stage. In other words, there should not be a simple rejection of all proposals on environmental grounds without proper consideration of the aspects of projected developments in Australia, which unfortunately has not taken place in the very emotional debate that has far too frequently blurred the reality of the environmental debate. As the annual report of the Resource Assessment Commission says:

SPEECH.PARA: Resource use decisions should seek to optimise the net benefits to the community from the nation's resources, having regard to efficiency of resource use, environmental considerations, ecological integrity and sustainability, ecosystem integrity and sustainability, the sustainability of any development, and an equitable distribution of the return on resources.

This sort of balanced approach, this sustainable development approach, seems to me and certainly the Opposition to be the rational way to look at the serious problems and the serious threats to the environment often posed by major developments. However, by having a rational and coherent analysis, one hopefully will get rid of the very emotional responses that so often take place.

I noted this week, for example, that a much more rational approach is being developed to questions of the ozone layer where, according to the Toronto Statement, the risk to the ozone layer appears to have been diminished by 80 per cent in terms of the threats apparently posed to the rate of diminution of the ozone layer by various emissions. As a result, of course, that more rational approach raises question marks over the sense of the Government's determination to adopt a reduction in emissions which may well, on the basis of the latest information, not be necessary. The annual report notes that:

Commonwealth decisions, policies and management regimes may provide for additional uses that are compatible with the primary purpose values for the area, recognising in some cases both conservation . . . and development interests can be accommodated concurrently . . . and in other cases, choices must be made between alternative uses or combination of uses.

That means that, instead of just rejecting out of hand many worthwhile and vital developments, in view of the terrible state of our balance of payments, on ecological or environmental emotional arguments, at least now we are going to have the opportunity through this Commission of having rational argument. The Opposition is strongly in favour of sustainable development being argued rationally instead of actions being taken on the basis of emotion.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 11 December, on motion by Senator Kemp:
