SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is now resuming the debate on two Bills, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) and the Debits Tax Termination Bill. I will speak briefly on the Debits Tax Termination Bill. The carriage for the Opposition of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) will be the responsibility of Senator Watson, who will speak later in this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: The Debits Tax Termination Bill proposes to transfer the responsibility for the bank account debits tax, formerly known as the BAD tax, from the Commonwealth to the States and Territories. At the same time it terminates the imposition of the tax by the Commonwealth. I make it clear at the outset that the Liberal and National parties are not opposing this Bill.

The Bill gives effect, as the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Crean) said in his second reading speech, to the announcement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on 19 July, in which he proposed a major review of Commonwealth-State relations and said that the Commonwealth would respond positively to the request made by some of the States to transfer the debits tax to them.

We welcome the Prime Minister's response in July to that request from some of the States, because it was in effect a response to a call that had been made by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) and the coalition some time earlier for a major review of Commonwealth-State financial relations. Indeed, in Dr Hewson's first press conference on becoming Leader of the Opposition, he listed Federal-State relations as the issue of the 1990s. That is a view with which I would fully agree because, if we look at the gamut of Federal-State relations and the impact that that has on the lives of every Australian, without doubt that relationship between the Commonwealth and the States-and also local government-has a major effect on everyone. It is a rusty arrangement; it is one that has never been as fully reviewed as carefully as it should, although there have been various attempts along the way. The 1990s, I think, will prove to be a critically important decade for the future of the Federation. In that context, it is entirely appropriate that we look at a full review of the Federal-State arrangement.

One of the major problems, of course, with Federal-State relations is the degree of fiscal imbalance that exists between the Federal and State governments. The Federal Government raises 80 per cent of the total tax revenue in Australia but is responsible for spending only 50 per cent of that. Conversely, the State governments raise a much smaller proportion of their expenditure requirements than the Commonwealth and therefore have to look to the Commonwealth for major financial assistance in order to be able to meet their expenditure requirements and responsibilities. That is, of course, to use the jargon, the vertical fiscal imbalance which has become increasingly an important issue for consideration and debate.

This Bill to terminate the Commonwealth's role in the debits tax-the bank account debits tax, as it was called-and to transfer the responsibility for the tax to the States is a very small start along the way to correcting the imbalance that exists. In monetary terms the amount involved for the remainder of the 1990-91 financial year in the tax transfer-which will start, as I understand it, from 1 December-is $190m or thereabouts. The full year of impact will see something of the order of $400m in increased revenue collections by the States, if the States decide to raise the tax themselves. That amount will be offset by a corresponding reduction in the general purpose payments to the States; so the net financial impact on the Commonwealth will be nil but the effect will be to make a very small start towards correcting the fiscal imbalance that now exists between the Commonwealth and the States. The smallness of it is highlighted by the fact that the total Federal Budget is something of the order of $96 billion-$96,000m. We are talking here of a figure of, say, $400m, which is very small in a proportionate sense but is certainly a worthwhile accretion or addition to the revenue base of the States.

What will be very important is how the States deal with this transfer to them of the responsibility for the tax. The tax itself can be said to be a tax which distorts financial markets and it is to be hoped that, now it is in the hands of the States, they will either reform it and look at it in relation to the other taxes they have on financial institutions or take other steps to remove the distortions that now exist. Certainly, I would not have thought that there was any need for the States-or any desire on their part-to continue with two financial duties which effectively tax both turnovers and net incomes.

For this variety of reasons, the Opposition has said that we will support the Bill. We believe that any genuine reform of Commonwealth-State relations must seek to redress the current fiscal imbalance and provide the opportunity to rationalise this country's plethora of taxes. The whole question of where we go in the area of Commonwealth-State financial relations is a very complex one. There is-rightly, I think-a general view held by both sides of politics that, in looking at correcting the fiscal imbalance that now occurs between the Commonwealth and the States, the Commonwealth should not be put in a position where it would be unable to exercise an effective fiscal policy. On the other hand, as we have seen in recent years, just because the Commonwealth has the fiscal policy levers in its hands does not mean it will do a good job with them. Indeed, the appalling recessionary state that Australia finds itself in today, at great cost and hardship to all Australians, is due very largely to a gross failure on the part of the Federal Government-the Hawke Government-to pursue a responsible fiscal policy.

So the argument that if one is to have responsible fiscal policy it has to be very strongly in the hands of the Federal Government as distinct from the State governments is not a one-way street. I think it is an argument that we are going to have to look at very carefully, dispassionately and objectively as we progress over the next few years in our major review of Commonwealth-State financial arrange- ments.

I might put on the record that the coalition has been, as I said earlier, very strongly of the view that there ought to be a major review of Commonwealth-State financial arrangements. On 21 June this year a meeting of all Liberal parliamentary leaders around Australia, Federal and State, was called by the Leader of the Federal Opposition, Dr Hewson. As a result of that meeting a communique was issued stating their support for `a genuinely federalist approach to Australia's future'.

We are very concerned about the degree to which power has moved towards Canberra and away from the States. This has been happening for many decades now-indeed, right through the history of Federation. Obviously there are some areas in which that has been desirable. I think there have been many areas in which it has not been desirable. I think that is what the debate is going to be about over the next few years. We want to know where we are going in terms of each of the aspects of Federal-State relations so that at the end of the day we will get a Federal system and a relationship between Federal and State governments that is in the overall best interests of all Australians, regardless of where they live. That is going to be a very difficult exercise. It is one that has been attempted on and off in a very ad hoc way for many years. It is important that we get our act together much more than we have in the past in addressing these issues.

As a coalition, we have welcomed the Prime Minister's belated moves in response to calls from the coalition to convene a series of Special Premiers Conferences to look at the matters I have been referring to. The first such Special Premiers Conference was held in October. It is regrettable that, despite Dr Hewson's request for the Opposition to be represented at that Conference in a spirit of bi-partisanship in terms of reviewing Federal-State relations, that request was rejected by the Prime Minister. This makes us wonder about the genuineness of the Prime Minister's call for a bipartisan approach in this area.

There was a lot of talk at the conference. Some worthwhile results emanated from it. But the main result of that first Special Premiers Conference was the establishment of a series of working groups or task forces to consider further many of the issues and items that were under the main heads on the agenda paper. The likely success or otherwise of the review of Federal-State relations that is under way in the form of those Special Premiers Conferences will remain to be seen and will be determined by the outcome of those working groups and the actions and decisions that may be taken on the basis of them.

I will not delay the Senate any further at this stage. I reiterate that the coalition supports this legislation to terminate the debits tax so far as the Commonwealth is concerned and to transfer responsibility for it to the States. We will watch with interest what that leads to.

There are a couple of points in the second reading speech of the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) and in the Bill which are not entirely clear. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, Senator McMullan, may be able to enlighten us on these matters when he is closing the second reading debate. My understanding is-I do not think this is contained in the Bill-that the transfer will take place as from 1 December. There is the question of 1990. There is the question of who will actually collect the tax.

As I understand it, the Australian Taxation Office is prepared to continue to collect on behalf of individual States until such time as they decide what they want to do. I also understand that a fee will be charged if those States invite the Australian Taxation Office to continue to collect the tax on their behalf. I do not think there are details in the Bill as to the nature of that fee or how it would operate. Senator McMullan may be able to enlighten us a little more in the course of the debate on this very interesting and worthwhile step that is being taken by the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Debits Tax Termination Bill 1990 which seeks to implement the Government's decision to transfer debits tax to the States. The tax was originally introduced by the then Treasurer, Mr John Howard, as the bank accounts debits tax, the delightful acronym of which is BAD tax. The tax was subsequently broadened to include other institutions and the name of the levy was altered.

SPEECH.PARA: The States already levy the financial institutions duty on deposits of financial institutions and this transfer will give the States control of this field of taxation. The Commonwealth will cease the imposition of the debits tax on a date to be proclaimed or six months after the Bill is given royal assent.

The Debits Tax Administration Act is the piece of legislation that describes how the tax is calculated and collected. This Act will remain so that outstanding amounts can continue to be collected after the imposition Act is terminated and existing legal action can continue concerning its provisions.

We believe that handing this tax to the States is an eminently sensible policy. Duplication will be avoided by maintaining the existing administration and collection arrangements, with the States simply receiving revenue which is collected on their behalf. It is understood that such an arrangement will be contingent on the State concerned mirroring the existing law currently operating at the Commonwealth level.

As the Bill stands, no revenue gains will be made by the States unless they alter the rate of the tax as the revenue foregone by the Commonwealth will be clawed back by the reductions in grants made to the States. On that basis, it is mainly a machinery provision to streamline the collection of tax and the flow of funds into State coffers. The Australian Democrats support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1990 incorporates a number of taxation changes that were foreshadowed in the Budget. I would like to take this opportunity again to remind the Government to get its legislation right the first time-not the second, third or even fourth time, as we have been accustomed to seeing in recent times. We have major concerns with the area of provisional tax-particularly the penalty provisions-which is introduced in this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: We believe that many of the provisions of the Bill concerning rebates for superannuation eligibility and provisional tax are completely inconsistent with the Government's stated objective of moving towards a simpler income tax system. I imagine it would be completely inconsistent with the principles of the Green Paper that was promised in August, again in September, and twice in October, which we are still awaiting. This Bill proposes to impose additional tax by way of penalty-this Government is great on penalising taxpayers-where a taxpayer overestimates the amount of tax instalment deductions from salary or wages in an application to vary provisional tax.

The amount of the penalty is to be calculated in these ways: firstly, for lump sum provisional taxpayers, 20 per cent of the overestimate of the tax instalment deductions; and, secondly, for instalment payers, 20 per cent per annum, with a penalty period as defined by section 221ya (1) and with a shortfall in instalment by virtue of the taxpayer's overestimate in relation to instalment deductions. This additional tax is an application of the self-assessment provisions that were foreshadowed in the Budget Papers. Unfortunately, as I mentioned earlier, the Government has not been able to get its act together. Budget Paper No. 1 states at page 4.12:
Extension to Certain Wage and Salary Income

To remove opportunities to defer the payment of tax on wages and salary, liability for provisional tax for 1990-91 and subsequent years will be extended to all cases where, in respect of the year preceding the year for which the provisional tax liability is to be imposed:
(i) a taxpayer with salary or wage income has a balance of tax to pay on instalments of $3000 or more; and
(ii) the shortfall of tax instalment deductions in respect of the salary or wages income of the income year is $3000 or more.
This is explained further in the next paragraph. The final paragraph of this section states:

In support of this change, the income tax law will be amended to include a new interest-based penalty where a taxpayer over-estimates the amount of tax instalment deductions from salary or wages income in an application to vary provisional tax.

To the extent that this is an interest-based penalty, I concur with that approach. On reading the Budget Papers, however, a taxpayer would be induced to believe that these changes to force directors and others who may receive one-off payments at the end of the year-such as judges, who do not pay tax until the end of the year-to pay their tax as close as possible to the period earned would have been incorporated into one piece of legislation. But this is not the case.

The first part of the change was incorporated into the Taxation Laws Amendment (Rates and Provisional Tax) Bill 1990, but the penalty regime is now contained in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1990. Why could not the Government get its act together and put these in the one Bill? Thus, the first rule for simplicity, grouping and collecting the same parts of a changed law into one Bill, is actually broken. The Government in its wisdom has chosen to extend the issue into two separate and unrelated Bills. Again, this is completely inconsistent with a government proposing to have a Green Paper on tax simplification. One would think that, if the Government were considering simplification of the tax Act, it would start to put its own ideas into practice.

The chamber has been advised by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) that the Green Paper on tax simplification was an important priority of the Government and the Treasurer (Mr Keating). I still believe it is. But we have been made to wait an unduly long time since the initial date that was promised for release. The delayed release of this paper is of considerable concern, given that we have been advised on various occasions that it would be part of the Budget or released some time after the Budget. We were given dates in September, mid-October, and late October. It is now December and we are still waiting; it is more than two months past the deadline. We must ask the Government, therefore, whether this noble priority is starting to wither on the vine.

The cynic may well observe that the Government is hell-bent on imposing more costs of compliance on taxpayers, adding pages of jargon to income tax legislation. We have seen, not only in this particular provision but also in other provisions-159, et cetera-that at the same time it adds some minor refinements in the name of simplicity. Is this Government still committed to simplifying the Income Tax Act? If it is, should the legislation before us not be reflecting that move towards simplification? Unfortunately, this does not seem to be the case. Clauses 21, 22, 25, 28 (8) and 32 reflect the accuracy of my comments.

To impose additional tax by way of penalty in situations of overestimating the amount of tax instalment deductions in an application to vary provisional tax is an extra burden, and possibly unnecessary. The Government admits that the revenue impact is negligible. So we are adding pages and pages to the Act for negligible impact. Not surprisingly, the people affected by this change have had cause to comment. The provisional tax change will cause hardship for many taxpayers.

It has come to my attention that many pensioners, some in their eighties, will be forced to pay up to 67 per cent of their pension in extra tax over a six-month period next year. The problem has been caused by the previous Bill-the Taxation Laws Amendment (Rates and Provisional Tax) Bill 1990. Representations as to the ramifications of this change were made to me only after the passage of the Taxation Laws Amendment (Rates and Provisional Tax) Bill 1990. However, the penalty regime for this change is now in the Bill currently before the Senate. Therefore, I mention it now.

To add insult to injury, many innocent people could be up for substantial penalties. Let me inform this chamber of the problems being caused by this provisional tax change. We acknowledge that Australia adopted the pay as you earn system in January 1946, and it is hard to argue against the PAYE system applied uniformly, but there are problems. The system has two elements: tax instalment deductions before payment of any salary, wages or pension; and provisional tax on other income.

Recently, instead of chasing taxpayers who had not deducted correct tax instalments-the employers-an easier way was to charge provisional tax if insufficient tax had been deducted during the preceding year. Again, there was a lack of proper enforcement. It has now come to my attention that the change will cause some extreme hardship for elderly pensioners. I am talking about people on Commonwealth security-type pensions. One 83-year-old retired United Kingdom serviceman will have to pay out about $16,000 in tax in March. With additional provisional tax, this will become $32,000. Further, he will need to pay another $8,000 as the quarterly instalment commences on 1 September. Naturally, he is worried.

Another elderly citizen is in similar circumstances, but has another $15,000 in additional annual income. This side of September, he will need to pay out more than half of his total income in extra tax. From his total income of just over $62,000, his total tax payments by September will come to $45,000. Lower down the income scale, another pensioner in his seventies, and grossing $23,000, must find another $4,000 by April.

When company instalments were altered, relief was given, although it became available only after the Opposition pointed out this problem on numerous occasions to the Minister then representing the Treasurer. So I ask the Parliamentary Secretary representing the Treasurer in relation to these Bills to again consider the provisional tax problem and how these changes will affect the elderly so that we do not have these initial distortions, complications and problems, particularly for the elderly.

It is not only the elderly who are outraged. In particular, the judges of this land have been shocked and outraged not only at the extra penalty but also at the whole system of inducing the judiciary into the provisional tax system. In order to pay provisional tax, the judges of this land will also be placed in grave financial hardship. The judges have not complained publicly, but they do resent the fact that they were never approached by the Government about the way the changes should be made.

At present, section 72 (iii) of the Constitution provides that the remuneration of Federal judges may not be diminished during their term of office. This is in the Constitution for very good reason. It is there to stop judges from being intimidated by government or being induced to take a course of action by a government. In fact, it helps to keep the independence of the judiciary intact. Changes to the tax law mean that the Federal judges will have to pay out a hefty payment in provisional tax, and this clearly reduces their remuneration. They will also have to pay arrears of PAYE tax instalments, and this will also reduce their remuneration or take-home pay.

The actual payments are as follows: the unheralded changes will mean that they will have to find almost $60,000 to pay provisional tax on their judicial salaries for this financial year, together with a payment of more than $50,000 for their salaries in the last financial year. At present, a judge's salary is about $124,000. Two tax payments totalling $111,000 will leave an after tax income of $12,500. So it is the transition that is really going to cause problems.

Whilst many judges go to the Bench after successful and lucrative careers at the Bar and may be able to find the extra $60,000, there are, on the other hand, other judges who may not have come from such lucrative backgrounds. Family Court judges are likely to be hardest hit, as comparatively few of them have had top earning practices at the Bar.
I must say that judges were not mentioned in the Budget statement in this area. The Treasurer stated:

To keep the tax system fair provisional tax arrangements will be extended to remove the scope for high income earners deferring tax payments on wage and salary income at the expense of ordinary taxpayers. This practice has been particularly prevalent in relation to director's fees, commissions and bonuses and short term employees.

Here comes the rub. Little did the Australian Labor Party Ministers realise at the time they were approving such changes that provisional tax would, under this provision, extend to their ministerial allowances.

In order to placate the wrath of the judiciary of this land, and contrary to what was stated in the Budget-and this is serious-the Attorney-General's Department now is offering another alternative to the judges, which is not surprising, given their wrath. They are being asked to join the PAYE group deduction system. I quote from a circular letter signed by the First Assistant Commissioner of Taxation, Richard Highfield, on 17 October 1990. He states:

Judges who commence now to have normal monthly tax instalment deductions made from his or her salary, say from 1 January 1991, may be granted an extension of time to pay any 1990-91 provisional tax without the imposition of additional penalty tax for late payment until 15 June 1991. This treatment takes into account the changed circumstances in which judges find themselves as a consequence of the tax instalment deductions not being required from their judicial salary.

He goes on to state that a judge will need to make his or her own arrangements for an extension of time with the office of the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation at which the 1989-90 return of income is to be lodged. Therefore, judges who now want time to pay their provisional tax, et cetera, will have to go and beg the Commissioner for an indulgence at the same time as they may be sitting on cases involving either the Commissioner or the Government. This further compromises the independence of the judiciary. It puts the judge in an impossible position-a position that is supposed to be prevented under section 72 (iii) of the Constitution.

Either the Government was blind to this obvious conflict when it introduced the previous Bill, and now this Bill, or it has done this deliberately. I should like to point out once again that this change was done without any consultation with the judiciary. As a consequence, the judges of our land are being put into the same category as those who are unfairly taking advantage of the tax system at the expense of ordinary taxpayers.

There is a contradiction of ethics and values here. Surely a judge is not a wilful tax avoider. What is happening is contrary to all the notions of natural justice which the judges require governments and other bodies to apply. Our judiciary should not be threatened. It assumes that the judges are employees, presumably employees of the Government.

At the Australian Legal Convention last year, the Chief Justice of the High Court, Sir Anthony Mason, referred indirectly to the problem of money and the exercise of power. He said that pressures were being placed on the judiciary in the way the courts are being forced to conform to a new religion whose deities were economical rationalism and managerial efficiency.

This year, a senior Victorian Supreme Court judge, Mr Justice McGarvie, identified some of the threats facing judicial independence and called for legislative changes to cover such matters as the removal of judges and magistrates; the protection of judicial salaries; the administration of the courts by the judges; and the protection of the Supreme Court and other superior courts from abolition. He said that there was a conflict between the Government and judicial independence and that there had been a disconcertingly high success rate for the Government interest.

Therefore, my biggest concern is to maintain the independence of the judges, as section 72 (iii) of the Constitution sets out to do, and this chamber should always be wary to continue this protection, as it is basic to our fundamental principles of democracy. It is our job to see that this chamber of review ensures that anomalies such as this do not creep into legislation.

Apart from the problem with provisional tax, the Opposition notes a number of other changes to the legislation. Firstly, there is the extension of the fringe benefits tax exemption to employers who make contributions to obtain priority of access in certain commercial care centres. Secondly, there is a modification of the availability of the capital gains roll-over relief provisions, where currently a limitation is applied in respect of the replacement cost not to exceed 120 per cent of the market value of the asset at the time of the loss. This is modified where assets are disposed of involuntarily, but in the case of a natural disaster, of course, that limitation is waived. So roll-over relief applies where the assets were acquired before 30 September, 1985, and destroyed as a result of natural disaster.

Thirdly, there is the extension of the availability of the principal residence situation for capital gains purposes during a taxpayer's temporary absence. All of these are welcomed. I think there are three or four parts, of which I will mention several. One provision concerns the dwelling not being used to produce income, and another says that it will not be necessary for the taxpayer to reoccupy the property prior to disposal. Again, they are welcomed.

However, there is a provision that I am quite unhappy about, and that concerns the rebate for superannuation contributions by employees. Again, it is a step in the right direction but the mechanics that have been employed to bring this about are indeed very messy; they are very long; and they total something like 13 pages of amendment. Recognising that they apply to people of middle and, particularly, low income levels, I find it quite unacceptable, because most of these people will find it necessary, in order to claim such deduction, to seek out an accountant or registered tax agent. The fees paid to this person will certainly diminish the effect of what really amounts to a fairly minimum sort of rebate that has taken 13 pages of enactment to express in this amendment. It is certainly a step in the right direction but it is complicated and messy.

It represents a consensus type of decision and the result in such circumstances is always confusing and not readily understood by the people to whom the provisions are going to apply. It applies to people who have a limited superannuation support-generally those with not more than $1,600 per annum. However, for identification and rebate purposes, a person will have to be a member of an eligible scheme.

A further limitation is also imposed by way of an income limit. The provision talks about `assessable' income up to $25,000. I would have preferred `taxable' but I should like a clarification on that particular point because that suggests that it is prior to deduction. While the maximum rebate goes up to $25,000, there is a sliding scale, opting out at the rate of 50c until the income level reaches $31,000, where it is completely lost.

This raises the question of two unknown factors, until after the year has actually ended, before the taxpayer can be fully aware of whether he can actually claim the benefit that he might be entitled to. This is another area for simplification. So a government committed to the notion of simplification should not have gone down this ponderous track to provide what I say is a very needy sort of benefit to encourage people to move into superannuation. We must encourage that at all costs, but we cannot say that this is the price we have to pay to get a simple income tax benefit.

The other issue is that there are changes to eligible termination payments, as I have mentioned, increases in the concessions for personal superannuation contributions and changes that ensure that the Income Tax Assessment Act complies as far as possible with the provisions of the Sex Discrimination Act 1984. Indeed, these are welcome. But there is also a technical correction which requires a new provision in this Act which overcomes deficiencies in relation to the tax file number quotation to a fund in order to comply with the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act.

I must not forget to mention the allowance for a tax deduction under section 78 of the Act whereby contributions to eligible charities and institutions, provided the payment by a taxpayer is $2 or more, qualify as eligible tax deductions. This has now been extended to Gifts to the Friends of the Duke of Edinburgh in Australia Award scheme. Also the Government has seen fit to extend by six months, to 31 December this year, deductions for contributions to Australian Vietnam Forces Welcome Home '87 Pty Ltd, the national memorial project.

There are also provisions exempting from income tax the pay and allowances of members of the Australian defence forces who are allotted for duty in parts of the Middle East. Again, we commend the Government on that particular provision. The last concession, I believe, is the least that we should be doing in respect of any members of our armed forces who are being sent into a possible area of war. The value of a life is inestimable. Therefore, I ask this chamber to take note of the concerns which have been expressed by the Opposition about the need for simplification of the Act and the need to give relief provisions to the hardships that are going to be caused as a result of the changeover legislation governing provisional tax and the need to maintain at all costs the independence of the judiciary of this land.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) is an omnibus Bill which proposes, amongst other provisions, to exempt from tax the pay and allowances of Defence Force personnel on operational service in response to the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. The exemption commences on 2 August 1990 with a total cost of $8.75m projected for 1990-91. As well, it is proposed to relax some parts of the capital gains tax so that where assets are destroyed by a natural disaster the replacement asset may exceed 120 per cent of the value of the destroyed asset, but the replacement must be substantially the same as the original asset. This is certainly a welcome amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: In addition, the four-year temporary absence rule for principal residences has been increased to six years retrospectively. That is, taxpayers will now be able to rent out their houses for up to six years and still retain exemption from capital gains tax. This will take account of some of the arrangements that people have to make in our society, where people change jobs and move residences considerably frequently.

The Bill also seeks to make some technical amendments to the treatment of excessive superannuation benefits derived after 1 July 1990. As well, it allows donations of $2 or more to the Friends of the Duke of Edinburgh Award in Australia Inc. made on or after September 1990 to qualify as being tax deductible. In addition, deductibility is extended until 31 September 1990 for two Vietnam forces benefits funds.

I foreshadow at this stage that I shall be moving an amendment which will seek to provide this tax deductibility to the Australian Nutrition Foundation Inc. The Foundation is a national non-profit community service organisation incorporated in Canberra in March 1981. It is a unique organisation devoted to promoting the nutritional health of Australians. It operates the national better health program which, amongst others, has identified nutrition as a priority area. I commend that particular amendment to the Senate.

The other provisions in the Bill include a technical amendment concerning the timing of the quotation of a tax file number when receiving a superannuation benefit to reduce the exclusion currently granted to taxation laws under the Sex Discrimination Act. All differences between married and de facto spouses are to be removed, and other discriminatory measures are made gender neutral. An example is the extension of the daughter-housekeeper rebate to include any child who performs housekeeping functions.

The Bill also seeks to introduce a penalty for the minimisation of provisional tax by overstating the amount of tax instalment deductions which are expected to be deducted during a year. The penalty is aligned to the recently passed measures imposing provisional tax on salary and wage income where no tax is deducted under the pay as you earn system and, as such, they complete effective provisions in that area.

Clause 4 of the Bill proposes to retain the current exemption from fringe benefits tax in respect of child-care facilities that are jointly funded by the Commonwealth Government and employers and to extend it where employers contribute to commercial child-care centres which qualify under the services for families with children program. Extending the fringe benefits tax exemption in this way will amount to an effective subsidy to commercial child-care centres. This exemption can in fact lead to a reduction in community child-care places if businesses purchase existing places. Of course, this is not the fault of the businesses and it would not be appropriate to deny the exemption. In fact, if community-based places are affected and their number is reduced, we must lay the blame at the feet of the Government and seek further effective action in that area.

The major provisions in the Bill concern the taxation treatment of contributions to superannuation funds. For people who have no employer contributions made on their behalf-for instance, self-employed people-and those whose only employer contributions are made under the so-called three per cent award superannuation clause, the existing limit on tax deductible contributions of $3,000 is to be increased to $3,000 plus 75 per cent of contributions in excess of $3,000. The only restriction is that the ultimate superannuation benefit must not be excessive.

These measures were announced in the 1989 Budget and then modified by a press release of 29 June 1990. The press release also introduced a proposal to introduce a limited tax rebate to employees who do not qualify for a tax deduction as stated above, and where the employer support is less than $1,600 per year. This is an additional benefit which should be supported. However, it is targeted to disappear completely when a person earns $31,000, which is only just above average weekly earnings. Our amendment, which shall be moved during the committee stage, aims to relax slightly the targeting so that the rebate disappears when a person earns $35,000 instead of $31,000.

The proposed relaxation to $35,000 will not affect the maximum limit on the employer superannuation benefit of $1,600. The system of providing such rebates is much more equitable than granting tax deductions and is supported by the Australian Council of Social Service. Maximum assistance can be granted to low income earners as opposed to high income earners who benefit from deductibility.

The Government is also proposing to extend the general anti-avoidance provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act, part IVa to the proposed rebates mentioned above. This should be supported. However, it seems to be a very partial measure. The Australian Democrats' alternative budget contained the proposal to extend part IVa to all rebates and foreign tax credits. An additional category, which should be scooped up in that way, is the withholding tax and schemes that are employed in that particular area. It is therefore recommended that the Senate supports the Democrats' amendments to broaden the scope of part IVa to include rebates and withholding tax as well as foreign tax credits.

Part IVa is the general anti-avoidance provision of the income tax legislation. It was the high-water mark of John Howard's legislative efforts against tax avoidance-Senator Watson might wish to note that. It has replaced the former provision-section 260 of the Income Tax Assessment Act-which was completely emasculated by the High Court decision of Sir Garfield Barwick. Ironically, some recent decisions concerning section 260 have actually given the provision the teeth it should always have had. Of course, it now no longer applies as part IVa has replaced it.

Part IVa has had the desired effect of discouraging most of the blatant artificial tax avoidance schemes. However, its scope is still too limited. As I have said, this Bill proposes to include one type of rebate under its ambit. We propose that all rebates be so included, just as all income and all deductions are included. Furthermore, foreign tax credits should be brought under the general anti-avoidance provisions.

The Taxation Laws Amendment (Foreign Incomes) Bill, which is still to be debated, is absolutely massive. It is essentially an anti-avoidance measure which encourages productive offshore investment. For convenience sake, I propose to move for the inclusion of the foreign tax credits under part IVa of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5).

An area that requires specific comment is the withholding tax. I will be moving amendments to bring in arrangements which attempt to avoid withholding tax under part IVA. The withholding tax has been in the news lately, and the news has not been good. A Melbourne academic, Ms Barbara Smith, has been fighting a battle to try to get a commonly used tax rort ended. The rort involves changing income, which would be subject to ordinary tax rates, into interest income which is supposedly earned by foreign lenders. Such interest is only taxed at 10 per cent. However, often the foreign lender is connected with the Australian resident, so the loan arrangement is merely a device to reduce taxation.

On 4 December 1990, the Australian Taxation Office submitted to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration estimates of revenue losses arising from interest withholding tax schemes. The estimates varied from $100m to over $600m per year. The Tax Office then made the somewhat incredible claim that, since about 50 per cent of the loans involved the largest corporations and some public bodies, these bodies would not risk being involved in questionable schemes. However, when we look at the success of the large corporate audit program being conducted by the Tax Office-it yielded some $600m this year-this is a somewhat bizarre claim.

Barbara Smith has been pursuing this matter for some time now. She has made submissions to the Committee. She has also provided information to the Tax Office. For her actions to protect the public revenue, she has been subjected to attack and to denigration in public by both a senior officer of the Tax Office, Mr Brian Nolan, and a senior tax professional who willingly admits that he used the device on blatant tax avoidance schemes.

It has also been reported that Ms Smith is merely seeking publicity rather than the resolution of the taxation issues. She has been accused of withholding information from the Tax Office by Mr Nolan and by Mr Liebler-an accusation she vehemently and, I believe, properly denies. Ms Smith has written to Mr Nolan seeking a public statement and a written verification of the fact that any information she has been offered has been immediately given to the Tax Office complete with the provider's name where that has been agreed. No such statement has been provided. In addition, at least one Melbourne tax official has been banned from talking to Ms Smith. In this case, there is no question about illegal transmission of information, merely a ban on a public official speaking to a member of the public.

That particular official was shifted to another office rather suddenly after he discussed the matter with Barbara Smith. Furthermore, her requests for documents under the Freedom of Information Act are to be referred to head office in Canberra. Senior Melbourne tax officers have refused to comment on this. The journalist, Roger Scott of Sydney's Sun-Herald, has reported this sorry tale, yet we still have had no adequate explanation. Surely Ms Smith is entitled to a public apology from Mr Nolan if his accusations prove groundless.

I conclude by summarising the amendments I shall move: firstly, to alter the phase-out of the tax rebate for superannuation contributions to end at $355,000 instead of $31,000; secondly, to extend part IVa of the Income Tax Assessment Act to apply to all rebates, withholding tax and foreign tax credits; and, thirdly, to grant tax deductibility for donations of $2 or more to the Australian Nutrition Foundation. There was to be a further amendment detailing the substantiation provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act--

TALK.START.PARA: —I have done that.

—Senator Watson commenced this debate by introducing a private member's Bill. I submitted a draft of amendments which take the debate a little further. I am now informed by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) that the Government is almost ready with a much more detailed amendment. In these circumstances, I have agreed to defer my amendment until the debate on Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) in the Senate next week so that we can compare the drafts and select the formulation which best meets the needs of taxpayers and the Tax Office.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is little wonder that the Australian Democrats have so little economic credibility. I was interested to hear Senator Spindler suggest that the rebate phase-out should be extended to $35,000, but I was fascinated that he advanced no particular justification for that. It sounds very much like the Democrats simply are wanting to be a little different. They are trying somehow to suggest some relevance but, more importantly, they did not put any cost on the effect of that initiative. What appalled me more than anything was that he seems to have swallowed the Government line on this whole change and simply picked up, at its most base level, the notion that somehow rebates are better than tax deductions and that that, therefore, leads inexorably to equity in the field.

SPEECH.PARA: I was amazed that Senator Spindler obviously did not have any comprehension of analyses that have been done of this particular initiative. If he had, he would have been acutely aware that the industry has regarded this as a complete disaster from the beginning. The Government has been roundly condemned for its total lack of consultation with the industry prior to the original Budget announcement in 1989. Most importantly, Senator Spindler simply failed to comprehend that the Government has absolutely changed its position. He talked about a slight modification and the introduction of a new rebate system as though this was all part of a positive approach of the Government.

What happened in the 1989 Budget was that we had, in respect of employees with little employer support and those with only award superannuation support, a firm commitment to tax deductibility. That was repeated in the run-up to the last election in the February 1990 Economic Statement. Then, without any warning at all, we had the height of dishonesty in the form of a press release put out by the Treasurer's office a couple of nights before the end of the financial year-on a Friday night after the close of business-to the effect that it would be too complex. This press release was four or five pages in length and was cleverly designed to disguise the fact that it constituted a comprehensive change of the rule. I think that it was probably quite successful in deceiving the financial journalists, because very little was written about it at the time or even subsequently.

The reality of the matter is that the Government finally announced in that notorious press release a very different proposal which was very narrow in concept; which, for no obvious reason, was targeted at the lower end of the market; and which has-according to CCH Australia Ltd-a number of very substantial inequities. That is why I thought Senator Spindler would have been jumping to his feet about the manifest social injustice of the outcome of this back down. But we did not hear a word of that; we simply heard the simplistic nonsense that, somehow, a rebate is better than a tax deduction.

Let me just deal with some of the proposals. It is not even clear-or it was not in the initial stages-whether or not one would be entitled to a tax deduction at all. One faced the prospect of waiting until the end of the year to find out whether the average employer contribution was in excess of $1,600. In the event that it was, one dipped out.

TALK.START.PARA: —You had to be part of a scheme first.

—One had to be part of a scheme, but one was also entirely dependent-in the classic roulette sense-on the activities of others. That meant that one could have faced the worst of all possible outcomes. One would not have got tax deductibility, the contribution would have been made on a false basis, and it would have been preserved until retirement age. So one would have got the worst of all possible worlds.

SPEECH.PARA: As I understand it, there has been a subsequent modification so that the test is now based on the prior income year. But I would be fascinated to hear from Senator McMullan in due course about the rationale for this whole structure. Why do we need to have such limitations as $1,600? Why do we need to have this $25,000 to $31,000 area with a cliff over which we fall and miss out completely once we are a dollar over the limit? Indeed, why do we not simply have what the Government's original intention was-that is, deductions available, presumably, to the limit of our reasonable benefit limits?

We are really talking, by and large, about employees who are very reluctant to make contributions. People are deserting this system in droves. We have got this nonsense of award superannuation which the Government pretends, somehow, covers 80 per cent of the work force. The reality is that something like 80 per cent of awards might have the three per cent written into them, with of course very little in terms of freedom of choice-but that is another debate. If we then look at the extent to which people are actually benefiting from those award entitlements, we find that there is massive non-compliance in the private sector: 60 per cent of private sector employees have no superannuation at all, despite the fact that they have got this nominal entitlement to the 3 per cent. If they realised that they have been diddled in this manner, I am sure they would be screaming.

The Australian Council of Trade Unions, which represents about one-third of private sector employees, took it upon itself to forgo a wage increase for these low income earners-and of course they had no say in it-on the basis that they would then pick it up by getting the first round 3 per cent. These low income earners have got neither. What a disastrous outcome! Can anyone blame employees for being exceedingly reluctant to get into the business of superannuation? That is what is happening.

The only people who are getting the increase are those in the public sector, where something like 90 per cent are actually getting their entitlements. I find it fascinating to look at the correlation between the level of unionisation in the public and private sectors and the extent of award entitlement-not coverage-in those two sectors. We find in the private sector that about 33 per cent of the work force has union coverage and about 40 per cent is getting the award superannuation.

Although the system has been in place since 1986, there is absolutely no sign of the trade union movement doing anything other than wringing its hands. The trade union movement has no incentive to extend it beyond its own membership, other than to talk about perhaps running a test case-I think that was Gary Weaven's best suggestion-or beefing up the inspectorate, which is Senator Cook's preferred option. But other than that, there are crocodile tears. We will continue to find that the vast majority of the private sector will vote with its feet and stay out of award superannuation schemes, at the same time that the award obligation is accruing day by day and has almost reached the $1 billion mark. It is accruing at the rate of about $17m a week, mainly for small businesses that have a very limited capacity to pay that 3 per cent, let alone to backdate it and somehow comply with an award, if they have been in default for some years. I just complete the analogy. According to the latest figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics, unionisation in the public sector is of the order of 75 per cent and the extent of entitlements is of the order of 90 per cent. So I think that there is a stark correlation there which tells us what this is all about.

Against that background, I would have thought that the Government would be interested in offering tangible incentives to induce low income earners to contribute voluntarily out of their own wage packets. Given that we are now in the recession we had to have, that is not an easy thing to do. Presumably, they are flat out making ends meet. It is not very likely that low income earners will turn around and decide that they have got a greater capacity to make contributions. They are being offered this very limited mickey mouse rebate scheme which is utterly incomprehensible and which, I am sure, will be greeted with the contempt that it deserves. As a result, we will simply have very little drain on the public purse. We are told that this great new initiative will cost something like $145m. I will be very surprised if it costs anything like that, for the simple reason that I cannot see how it is going to be attractive in any way. Let me run through some of these inequities that obviously Senator Spindler is not aware of. As the CCH says:
From an administrative standpoint there can be no doubt that the new arrangements are far better than the previous arrangements.
In other words, that is what was foisted on the industry back in August 1989. It continues:

The only responsibilities now on funds where all members receive non-award employer support are: to advise members whether or not it is an eligible scheme and, where it is, to preserve the member finance benefits.

That is great. As far as the funded administrators are concerned, life is a lot easier, and the ferocious behind the scenes struggle to modify these unworkable arrangements has succeeded to that extent. But if we look at the object of the exercise and see who benefits from it, by way of analysis, CCH had this to say:
However, to achieve that administrative simplicity, substantial areas of inequity, relative to the previous proposals, have been introduced.
I run through them:

Basing the rebate on the average level of support in a scheme can, at best, only produce broad equity. Any members who are denied a rebate because of higher paid or higher support employees in the same scheme or category will feel somewhat cheated.

Category, as I understand it, is capable of being defined however one likes. On the face of it, one could have each employee in a firm in a separate category. From the employee's point of view, that might be one way of achieving the desired result. But assuming that that is some sort of artificial device and it is going to be caught by the successor to section 260, the name of which I cannot remember any more, then we will find that those employers will be at risk through no fault of their own, through no action over which they have any control. They can simply become ineligible because there are other higher paid employees in the firm who are getting more superannuation benefits and, as a result, the average goes over this magical $1,600 figure.

Where is the equity in that? Surely if one targets a particular group, one wants to provide it with that benefit and not have it taken away from it by persons and factors outside its control. That is like saying, `We will give you an unemployment benefit unless we decide the Budget deficit is too high, in which case you will forfeit it. Sorry, but that is the way things are. It will automatically operate because of extraneous factors beyond your control'. That would be an outrage under any other system, but that is what is contemplated here.

The second proposition is that an employee with award contributions plus, say, $1,200 a year of non-award superannu- ation support will be treated more favourably for tax purposes than an individual with a similar level of total support, all of which is non-award. There is no logic in that; it is simply an arbitrary and artificial distinction. Thirdly, a large cliff applies to the rebate. If one's non-award super is $1,599, one will get the full rebate; if one is one dollar over that, one will not get any rebate at all. In every other area of the social security system we seem to have phase-out arrangements. I do not know why we do not have them here-presumably because it is all just too difficult and this arbitrary figure has been chosen as a result and will be applied irrespective of the consequences.

The fourth example of inequity is that some employees are now entitled to tax deductions for contributions while others are entitled to rebates. The result is not the same. In fact, it is generally more advantageous to be entitled to a rebate, because that is equivalent to a deduction of 40 per cent because a 15 per cent contributions tax does not apply and the contribution counts as undeducted contributions for RBLs and benefits tax purposes. I suppose the Senator Spindlers of this world would say, `That's all right. It is not a level playing field but as long as rebates are better than tax deductions that is fair enough'. It is not fair enough between employees and that is really what we ought to be talking about. Where is the equity in a result of a two-tiered outcome such as that? Again, it is because of factors beyond the control of the employee. It is simply a function of a series of artificial limits imposed by this latest nonsense.

The fifth example of manifest inequity is that employees with award-only support and salaries over $31,000 can obtain a tax deduction for personal contributions but no tax concession is available to simi-lar employees with similar support outside the award process. Again, I would be very interested to hear the rationale for that. Employees who do not qualify for a rebate but are members of an eligible scheme will have their contributions preserved despite the fact they received no tax concessions on those contributions. I think I made that point earlier. Some employees will be disqualified from any tax concessions as a result of being a member of a plan which was not an eligible scheme even though the period of membership was very short. Again, for reasons beyond their control, they might miss out altogether, but end up with their contri- butions being tied up although they cannot get any tax concession for them.

The devastating conclusion is that overall the new arrangements are probably better and fairer than the rules which we have applied up to now. However, the latest announcements remove many of the positive features of the announcements made in last year's Budget. Where is the gain from all that pain? I suppose it is too much to expect that the Government would actually have been honest in its elaboration of the reasons for its back-down. No doubt a gentleman of the stature of the Treasurer (Mr Keating), who has all the time in the world to make off-the-cuff pronouncements about how much he would be able to turn the country and the economy around if only he were given unfettered ability and was not constrained by such things as numbers in Caucus, Prime Ministers who have outstayed their welcome, ungrateful media and carping oppositions, would have been able to attend to some of these inequities. But no, the industry constantly tells me-and I presume it also tells Senator McMullan, because I am sure he has consulted widely-that it cannot believe the lack of consultation that goes on.

We know that Senator McMullan has been working on this tax simplification exercise which presumably will involve superannuation simplification in due course. The Government obviously has been sitting on that for some months now, presumably because of the economic statement next February, which at this stage is being vehemently denied but no doubt it is in the course of preparation and we might hear something about it at that time. It is cold comfort for those who had expected that by the time the legislation was introduced we have would been able to evolve a system which was satisfactory and equitable. Instead we have neither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will deal with the two Bills in sequence and speak firstly to the Debits Tax Termination Bill. Firstly, I apologise to the Senate and particularly, in his absence, to Senator Short that the Government's proposed amendment to this Bill was not available to him before he spoke. That was unintended and I apologise for it. The situation was rectified as soon as I found out about it.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Short referred to the arrangements for the transfer and subsequent collection of the tax after it is transferred to the States. The Government amendment will make it clear that the transfer will take place on 1 January. As he indicated, the arrangements for collection, as is authorised by the legislation, will be based on negotiations between the Australian Commissioner of Taxation and the counterpart officers of the State and Territory authorities. All the State and Territory authorities, I understand, except the Australian Capital Territory, have now passed legislation or are at a sufficiently advanced stage to approve the final passage of the necessary legislation. I am advised that the negotiations are proceeding sufficiently for a 1 January start-up in all those areas.

Senator Short asked whether there would be a fee for the collection. That is ultimately a question of the outcome of those negotiations, but I would be very surprised if there was not a fee for the provision of service. I am sure the States would be even more surprised. Had Senator Short seen the amendment, I am sure he would have appreciated that. I regret the fact that the amendment was not available to him.

Broadly, I agree with the other part of what he said-but not some of the rhetorical flourishes he put around it-that, while this is not in itself a major change in Commonwealth-State relations, it is an important step in the major process now under way and, both symbolically and of itself, it is a very worthwhile measure and enhancement of Commonwealth-State relations. Apart from saying that, I commend the Debits Tax Termination Bill 1990 and reiterate that I will move the Government amendment at the committee stage.

The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) has a large number of elements and it would be inappropriate in these circumstances to go through a recounting of them all. That was essentially done on behalf of the Government in the second reading speech. Let me deal with some and then with some of the points raised in the debate. In macro terms, it is not a Bill that constitutes any major policy changes. There are a lot of minor matters, which are important to some individuals, but as a matter of macro-economic management or tax policy there are no major changes. There is the implementation of past Budget decisions, particularly with regard to superannuation contributions. The Bill deals with the important although uncontroversial question of the exemption from tax of the pay and allowances of Australian Defence Force personnel involved in the response to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. I appreciate the fact that everyone supported that.

The Bill modifies the tax laws to comply with the Sex Discrimination Act, which is part of the program to reduce exemptions under that Act. There are a lot of what I would call `minor' measures, although they may be important to many individuals and organisations-for example, those regarding eligible termination payments and the excessive components of those. There is also the fringe benefits tax matter, to which Senator Watson referred, concerning employer child- care contributions; that is, extending that exemption to payments made to a com- mercial child-care centre.

I do not want to go into the Bill itself more than that, and I do not want to pursue Senator Spindler's amendments too much because we will do that in the committee stage. I simply indicate at this stage that we are not supporting any of those amendments, and I will make more detailed comments at the time. We have different levels of opposition to the amendments. Some we oppose because we think it is the wrong way to go about things; others we think are at least premature.

At the moment I would say that we are not persuaded by the third amendment to do with part IVa. It is not that we are opposed to the endeavour in principle, but we are not persuaded that it is necessary or even useful. With an already complex piece of legislation, adding further proposals and propositions where to us there is no apparent benefit is, we think, inappropriate.

I should say something about the question of simplification. It got a couple of honourable mentions. Without disclosing anything, can I say that a very little patience will do a bit of good on that matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —That means a February statement, does it?
—Would Senator Alston like to bet $100 a day that he is wrong?
—What about a March statement?
—What about $200 a day-in fact, your old fee per day?
—So you are going to put out a press release on Christmas day.

—I will even have $100 a day for you on that. I cannot say much more about that. It is not my prerogative, but it sounds like it could be a very profitable day for me if only I could get some takers. There were some important questions raised by senators, and I want to deal with those a little more seriously than in that throwaway line, which I did enjoy and the significance of which will be apparent to all honourable senators in the not too distant future.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Watson raised a couple of questions about provisional tax changes. While I share his proper concern for the independence of the judiciary, I for one have never felt that that independence was dependent upon their independence from the tax system. I continue to have that view. The provisional tax system will catch a large number of people. There is a need for appropriate transitional arrangements. They are being implemented.

Judges are not unique in that sense. If they in the main are making sensible and appropriate arrangements to pay in the same manner as all other Australians have been required to pay for many years, I do not think it is appropriate that we make special arrangements for them. But I think that it is necessary and appropriate that they and others who confront transitional problems with what is, I think, an entirely appropriate change, not targeted at judges, should make other accommodations such that in future I expect the outcome to be appropriate. In my view, a much more important point that Senator Watson raised was the potential of adverse consequences for pensioners and other people like them. I am somewhat more concerned about their economic circumstances than those of judges.

Senator Watson would know this, but can I just say for the record that nobody who receives any of the pensioner rebate will be paying provisional tax. Any person who gets any part of that rebate is exempt from paying provisional tax. That remains the case. That does not cover every aged person, but it covers all people in that category. I think that is appropriate. I am advised that for 1990-91 pensioners are exempted from paying provisional tax where their 1989-90 taxable income was, for single pensioners, less than $15,667. I understand that Senator Watson raised another example and that some individuals-not pensioners in the sense to which I am referring-can still be--

TALK.START.PARA: —I did exclude those.

—I was only saying for the record that I understand that what I am saying does not contradict what Senator Watson said. I just wanted to make sure that there was no misunderstanding by anybody who may have the misfortune to have to read all this. I expect that there will be a very small number of people reading it, possibly none.

SPEECH.PARA: While we are dealing with that matter, it is important to say that, obviously, we cannot bring in a measure that will raise a large amount of revenue and have nobody worse off. Obviously, as a matter of logic, it is not possible. It is conceivable that in all such changes some individuals may be adversely affected in the transition either because of the way the provisional tax in this instance falls upon them in the first year of its operation or because it takes them a while to restructure their financial arrangements.

I would say as a generality, particularly with regard to judges, that if any individual finds himself significantly adversely affected in a manner other than that intended by the legislation-that is, he is not adversely affected simply because he has been caught doing something he should not have been doing; I am talking about honest taxpayers who are suffering a short term inconvenience because of transitional arrangements-I simply suggest that he take up the standing opportunity to consult with the Australian Taxation Office about arrangements that might ease that problem for him if he is confronting it.

I do not want to pursue every rabbit that Senator Alston sent running down several burrows in the course of his rather discursive contribution. It did seem to me to have some problems within it. I understand that the Opposition's role is to raise a lot of questions-and there is nothing wrong with that-but yesterday I was involved in a debate here in which Senator Boswell said that all these small businesses were going broke because of superannuation payments. Now we find that Senator Watson says that none of them are paying them. They cannot both be right.

We have also had two questions being pursued about simplicity, on the one hand, and, on the other hand, the need sometimes in the pursuit of that to have what otherwise are arbitrary arrangements and limits. It is true that from time to time there is in tax, as in everything else, a trade-off between the several objectives of equity, efficiency and simplicity. We all know that. It is a question that has been the subject of debate in every forum in which tax is discussed. To make the point that those three things involve a trade-off is to make no new point at all.

The Government has spent five years of tax reform essentially concentrating on equity, and we certainly intend to try to maintain that priority. But it is appropriate that a large number of people approach us about the simplicity question, particularly with regard to superannuation. That is a complex matter which is difficult to resolve. It will take quite some time. We will always need to weigh all those factors in the equation. I do agree with the part of Senator Alston's contribution in which he read from CCH saying that current arrangements under this will be better and fairer than those which previously existed. I think that is important and correct.

The only other overall points that I feel need to be made in this debate relate to Senator Spindler's Blue Hills saga about Ms Smith. I do not wish to say too much about it. We have all had a few goes at debating this around the Parliament and publicly. I simply say that it does not enhance public debate to believe every rumour that one hears, even if it is a rumour which, if true, would make it easier to balance one's notional budget. If there were $1 billion dollars out there that one could get back to balance the notional budget so much more easily, that would not make the rumour true. Governments and in fact parties which aspire to government need to deal with facts.

TALK.START.PARA: —That does not apply to the Democrats.

—I was being generous to Senator Alston. That is very rare, I know, and I do not blame him for missing it, but that was my intention at the time. I do not want to pursue that; it is a fair way away from this Bill. I will say a bit more about it when I say why I do not support the Australian Democrats' amendment. I simply say that in fact the Martin committee, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Fin- ance and Public Administration, is conducting a very important inquiry that incorporates an examination of that, and the Commissioner of Taxation went before the Committee quite recently and it seems to me, from what I have been able to glean of what was said by him and to him, that the matter has been put in a much clearer and more objective light now than previously. I do not think we want to pursue that tangent any further here. I will make my comments in detail on amendments in the committee stage.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Watson raised the question of assessable income. To make sure there is no misunderstanding, I want to say something about that. Senator Watson is correct-the income test threshold for the new superannuation rebate is based on assessable income and not taxable income. This provides a much simpler test. It is easier to measure, and for the people targeted for the rebate it is not expected that there will be a significant variation between the two, so we opted for that. But he is correct and I thank him for drawing it to our attention.

It is important in regard to another point, too, which we will come back to in the committee stage. It is important to realise that the cut-off figures-for example, the $25,000-are cut-off figures for assessable income, which is different from salary. So if we are trying to make an average weekly earnings cut-off, we do not want it to be the same level as it would be for assessable income. The distinction is important. I will not labour that; the logic is obvious. I simply want to put it on the record in this second reading debate. I thank honourable senators for their support for the legislation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

SPEECH.PARA: We have reservations as to the particular technique that has been used in these circumstances whereby we have members of an upper House in a minority position trying to impose their Budget priorities on a properly elected Government from the lower House. I think that there is a responsibility on members of this chamber corporately and individually to ensure that the Senate is a House of review. As it is not the House of government, we must discharge our responsibilities to ensure that the legislation is correct and does not infringe on personal liberties and the like.

To start having a Dutch auction as to who can provide the greatest list or the most qualified institutions or bodies for section 78 deductions I do not think is appropriate. I therefore ask the Democrats: why stop at just the Australian Nutrition Foundation Inc.? There are hundreds of similar bodies that could well qualify, and I believe that to adopt this course of action would be to introduce an unfortunate precedent in this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —I express some regret at the decision of the coalition and query the reasons put forward by Senator Watson. There are numerous occasions on record where the Opposition has moved amendments to the Budget provisions of the Government of the day. I believe that the role of the Senate is not only as a House of review but also as a House that looks after the people that are forgotten by the executive government. If it takes that role seriously, that is not a valid reason.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like the Opposition, the Government will not be supporting this amendment, as I indicated before. There are essentially two reasons. The Australian Nutrition Foundation wrote to me about this matter and I have already advised it-in fact, on 20 August-that there is very little prospect of the income tax gift provisions being amended to include that body. That is a statement I could make about hundreds of very worthy organisations in Australia, many of which I am a member. That does not mean that those organisations ought to receive tax deductibility for donations.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a very fine mesh that is put across this particular channel to protect it from the thousands of bodies which seek tax deductibility for donations to them. That is not to say that the bodies that do not receive this tax deductibility are less worthy than many of those that do. The history of this section has been riddled over the years with anomalies. Anybody who is prepared to delve into those is much braver than I am or anybody I have ever met. It is important, therefore, that we keep a discipline in the manner in which we deal with these matters. The fundamental premise of the Government in dealing with this matter is virtually that there are no new bodies admitted. We start from that premise and very occasionally vary it at the margin for special cases. That will continue to be the case.

If the Government felt that the Australian Nutrition Foundation was playing a role of such importance that it ought to receive government support, then the most appropriate thing to do would be to make a grant to it in the Budget. If the Government wants to give taxpayers' money to some other organisation-there is nothing wrong with that and we do it often; there are grants-in-aid under very many Acts of Parliament-it ought to be done explicitly and transparently and through legislation. The Government will not be agreeing to this or any similar proposals that bob up out of debate generally. We try to give consideration to the bodies that write to us and do not just reject them as a matter of course, but it is very rare that one gets through the mesh.

I say in conclusion, however, as I said in my letter to the Nutrition Foundation, that it is quite possible that there will be circumstances in which gifts made to it may still qualify for a deduction. Depending upon the circumstance in which the taxpayer carrying on a business makes that gift, it could well be said to have a relationship with the production of a taxpayer's assessable income. That applies to all organisations, and they ought not to fail to take that possibility into account in seeking support. The Government does not consider it appropriate to add in an ad hoc and random manner bodies such as this to the section 78 exemption, and we will be opposing the amendment accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that the amendment does not warrant a long debate. SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Debates about somewhat arbitrary limits-such as whether a cut-off point should be at $25,000 worth of assessable income or whether the phase-out should be at 30c in the dollar or 50c-are always difficult because it is very rare that we have the comfort of secure, agreed objective criteria. We all have to make best estimates and ask: what is a reasonable balance between equity, simplicity and revenue implications? That is always a question of judgment.

SPEECH.PARA: The most fundamental thing about this amendment is that there is not one skerrick of evidence to say that the $35,000 cut-off point has any greater merit than $31,000. I am not trying to lift $31,000 to some element of objective purity; it is a best estimate, working from the $25,000 starting figure for the phase-out. As I said, it is assessable income, not salary, so it relates to a somewhat higher salary level than $25,000, but it is not possible immediately to say what that will be.

With that starting point, the 50c in the dollar was a simple calculation. It always seems to be a fair starting point. In certain circumstances there may well be a case for varying it, but I think the onus of proof is why it should be varied. I do not share a lot of the views expressed by Senator Alston about the proposal as a whole. I was tempted to make a somewhat longer contribution in the second reading debate on what he had to say. I think some of his criticisms of that part of the amendment are valid. There would be a higher revenue cost for this concession if we extended it.
