There is no objective evidence to say that the figure selected is in any way superior or more appropriate than that which has been set in the legislation.

I think we need to proceed on the basis of the understanding that the industry and the affected individuals have. Should subsequent evidence indicate that an alternative level would deliver a more appropriate result, we will deal with that problem when it arises. We cannot all guess and have a `pin the tail on the donkey' game in the Committee. We have to proceed on the basis of sensible balanced estimates of the various factors. The best estimate we can make is that this phase-out is the most appropriate. I urge the Committee to stick with the proposal put forward in the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I indicated previously, the Government will not be supporting this body of amendments-not because we are any less concerned about tax avoidance than the Australian Democrats but because, on the best analysis we can make, we cannot find the tax avoidance with which they are trying to deal. If we extended part IVa of the Income Tax Assessment Act to all rebates, withholding tax and foreign tax credits, it would be hard to find a circumstance in which any avoidance scheme under any of those arrangements would not already be covered, because we would be creating a situation in which what should otherwise be assessable income is no longer assessable income, and that ought to be able to be dealt with under part IVa.

SPEECH.PARA: As honourable senators would know, there are four broad categories of rebate in the income tax law which might be affected by this extension. The first covers those given to people because of their particular circumstances, such as the dependent spouse rebate. On the face of it this is not likely to be the subject of tax avoidance arrangements; if it is, we do not think part IVa is the best solution to the problem.

The second type of rebate, which is not quite so common, is designed to encourage people to incur expenditure on particular activities that the Parliament has determined from time to time to be worth while or desirable. For example, it may be a rebate to encourage people to invest in a particular type of company. An extension of part IVa to cover these rebates would seem inappropriate if it prevented people from entering into what might be called arrangements to take advantage of such rebates. That is what we want them to do in respect of those sorts of rebates. We want them to invest in those things and take advantage of the rebates. It means that there is more expenditure in the area affected.

The third category covers rebates given to taxpayers with a particular type of income-that is, the rebate for dividends received by companies. If, under this heading, people are entering into arrangements to substitute what is really a particular type of income with a type of income that is rebatable, it would be our expectation and understanding that part IVa would apply to that already. So we do not see under that extension that there is any potential for tax avoidance that is not already covered.

If the concern is that the payment of withholding tax on interest and dividend income is being avoided, once again it is not apparent why part IVa would not already apply. Similarly, under the foreign tax credit arrangements, if one wants to obtain credit it is necessary to obtain some foreign income. If foreign income is being substituted for other non-rebatable income that should have been included in accessable income, part IVa would cover such a situation already.

So our view at the moment is that the amendments are well intentioned but do not achieve any public policy purpose. If the Democrats, their advisers or the people who put this proposal before them have some evidence that would indicate that some extension of part IVa is necessary to deal with a tax avoidance problem of which they are aware and we are not, I would appreciate it if this could be brought to our attention. The objective is appropriately stated. I simply think the amendments do not achieve the objective and, therefore, we oppose them.

DEBATE.TITLE: EXCISE TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL 1990CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL 1990PETROLEUM EXCISE (PRICES) AMENDMENT BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 October, on motion by Senator Collins:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating as allied Bills the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill 1990, the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1990 and the Petroleum Excise (Prices) Amendment Bill 1990. The two Bills which relate to resources will be dealt with by Senator Parer; that is, the Petroleum Excise (Prices) Amendment Bill 1990 and the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill 1990. I will be taking the first Bill listed, the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1990, on behalf of the Liberal and National parties.

SPEECH.PARA: Briefly, this Bill contains eight sections and amends the Customs Tariff Act 1987. Schedule 1 reduces the rate of duty for articles of vulcanised rubber from the current 2 per cent to a free rate of duty. Schedule 2 amends the subheading `Description of certain fabrics' and extends the scope of item 41a of Part III in schedule 4 to include lightweight wool fabrics. Schedule 3 omits and inserts a new item 44 to extend this item to goods of New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Forum Islands and developing country origin. Schedule 4 removes items made redundant due to the sunset entry provisions having expired on the 31 December 1989. These items were part of the chemical and plastics industries assistance arrangements announced by the Government in 1986.

The deletion of New Zealand rates of duty from heading 5903, the incorporation of badges, labels, logos and such in apparel without the application of separate tariff agreements and the putting in place of the tender quota rates for textiles, clothing and footwear goods are contained in schedule 5. Schedule 6 deletes redundant duty rates where phasing rates have been implemented and closes subheadings where common rates of duty have been reached.

Schedule 7 revokes an item which allowed duty free entry of goods for Commonwealth departments and instrumentalities. Amongst the changes in schedule 8 is a change to duty free entry for protein concentrate, coal tar and pitch, an amendment to the treatment of ride-on motor mowers, and the assignment of a more specific description of certain goods of cardboard and paper.

Many of these changes are minor or administrative; some of them are long overdue. They correct anomalies such as existed in the case of ride-on mowers, and particularly in reference to imported light weight woollen fabrics. Wool is a matter of great importance at present with the difficulties in selling the product overseas. It is certainly very much in Australia's interest to promote the use of wool in whatever way we can. In recent years, with the development of lightweight wool-which is a high quality product used both in male and female clothing-there has been a very longstanding anomaly where we have had a high rate of duty on the importation of these lightweight wool fabrics, which has put an unnecessary penalty on our manufacturing industry. That has now been removed by this Bill.

Two aspects of the Bill that I wish to comment on very briefly are the textiles, clothing and footwear (TCF) quota schedule and the matter that relates to the Commonwealth and its instrumentalities not being able to get goods in free of customs duty, as has been the case up to the present. In financial terms, special attention to the textiles, clothing and footwear related changes is pertinent because of the value of the tender allocation for 1990-91, which has been raised by 20 per cent above the 1989-90 levels. Increased imports are expected to raise an additional $101.6m in customs revenue.

The increased tender allocation is in line with the textiles, clothing and footwear plan introduced on 1 March 1989, the objective of which is to encourage industries that are efficient, internationally competitive and export oriented and make them less reliant on community support within Australia. The Liberal Party and the National Party support this objective. We would like to see the textiles, clothing and footwear plan accelerated, at least to the extent that quotas are abolished ahead of schedule. The Industry Commission (IC) has estimated that the cost of tariff quotas is equivalent to an estimated 40 per cent consumption tax on TCF products which are produced by a fragmented sector in Australia. In 1987 there were over 3,000 enterprises involved in the textiles, clothing and footwear sector.

The assistance levels given to the textiles, clothing and footwear sector are the highest for Australian manufacturing industry. The cost of this protection to the consumer is estimated to be around $1 billion per annum. It is worth observing that a large part of that is essential expenditure; some of it certainly is discretionary with respect to some garments. Everyone has to be clothed and everyone has to be shod, and an extra $1 billion, particularly on the poorer sections of the community-the less well off-is a very significant impost.

The great impact that this high level of tariff protection for the textiles, clothing and footwear industry imposes on the Australian community is not often noted in the cost of living assessments in Australia. The IC estimated that the average effective rate of protection on the textile segment was 74 per cent in 1988-89, or roughly 4 1/2 times the average for manufacturing industry. It was 150 per cent for the clothing industry and in excess of 200 per cent for footwear. That is more than 12 times the average for Australian manufacturing industry.

The aim of the TCF plan is to force the restructuring of this sector to open it up to the reality of competition. It is very interesting that, despite all the doom and gloom talked about the TCF plan by some sectors in the past-to the effect that any let-up in the levels of tariff protection would spell the end of the industry-the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority made the following comment in its 1990 report on the state of the industry:

Significantly, the adjustment pressure of the past year has arisen largely because of adverse economic conditions and the abrupt ending of a prolonged period of demand growth in the TCF industries. Any effects attributable to the TCF plan have only been minor to date.

There is no question that the textiles, clothing and footwear industry needs to be restructured. That restructuring means increasing the use of advanced technology and more effective work management practices.

During the first 11 months of 1989-90 the total value of clothing imports was 20 per cent higher than a year earlier. Imports from Fiji jumped by more than 40 per cent while imports from New Zealand jumped by 78 per cent, a consequence of the closer economic relations agreement. The biggest surge in clothing imports this financial year came from China, which lifted its exports of apparel and clothing accessories to Australia by 25 per cent in the first 11 months of last year. Over the same period, TCF exports rose by 120 per cent-from $651.1m to $1,636.5m. Two years before in 1987 this export component represented about 5 or 6 per cent of total production. It is interesting to note our place in the global market. In 1986-87 Australia ranked thirty-eighth on the world textile exporting scale and fifteenth on the world textile importing scale.

There is no reason for those involved in the textiles, clothing and footwear sector to fear lower levels of tariff protection. Provided relevant and intelligent changes are made to the industry, it will not only survive but also prosper. But it will be very different from what it is today; there will be different people in it and they will be doing different things.

From a national point of view, it is quite incredible that there is so little pro- cessing of the natural fibres that we produce in this country-namely, wool and cotton. There is very real financial gain in sending wool and cotton out of Australia other than in wool bales or cotton bales. If we can process the fibre further we do make very significant value added gains to the Australian economy. If we are going to do that there will have to be some significant changes in our union-dictated work practices so that the most efficient technology can be installed and that technology can be used efficiently. Any sort of further processing is of benefit to us even if it is only a first step towards manufactured garments. We ought to be aiming to go as far down the chain as is possible. We certainly ought to be weaving and preparing our own fabrics and we ought to be looking at using those fabrics, probably the high quality ones, in manufactured goods.

As recently as the 1950s and the 1960s this country produced the finest wool suitings in the world. The Yarra Falls men's suitings, for example, were world famous. Today we produce very little in the way of fabrics. The reason we do not produce them is simply the self-indulgent work practices we follow. Modern automatic weaving machines are very expensive and they can be made to pay only if they run 24 hours a day, seven days a week. That is 168 hours a week-not the 36 hours at best that they do at present. The union movement, of which the Australian Labor Party is the parliamentary wing, will not allow what is only economic commonsense to take place. So we end up producing the natural fibres and having to buy the manufactured fabrics back in from overseas.

We can never match the very low wage structure of Third World countries, particularly in the mass production of garments. It is therefore incumbent on us to exploit what advantage we have in being the source of the natural fibres and exploiting fully the benefits of advanced technology to develop particular sections of the textiles and clothing industry. If we do that, and we can do that successfully, we will see an expansion of the industry within Australia. For these reasons the Liberal Party and the National Party support this Bill. We are committed to a phased and predictable reduction in protection, alongside structural reforms in areas such as the labour market and the transport and telecommunications section.

The second point I wish to raise concerns the amendments to schedule 4 of this Bill. The amendments to schedule 4 relate to the imposition of a charge equal to customs duty on imports. In his second reading speech the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) stated:
This change places public service managers on the same footing as private enterprise managers whereby purchasing decisions will be made on the full duty paid price.

The argument behind that is that it puts imported goods for Government departments on precisely the same plane, on a level playing field-to use the cliches of today-as Australian industry. On the surface, it is a very attractive move. The reality of the situation is that those benefits may well be quite illusory. In the first place, Australian Government departments do not pay customs duty; they pay a fee said to be equivalent to that. The compilation of that fee will be based purely on the nominal rates of customs duty for those goods. It will not have to include any of the economic hedging that has to be built into a customs agent's fees to cover the liability for incorrect description of goods or things such as that, for which the Government has now very heavily penalised any misstatements. The actual payment of the fee will not be quite equivalent to what private industry will face.

Secondly, it really is a little bit nonsensical to say that the Government will be in a zero cost operation. One of the objections has been from the Department of Defence, which finds that it has a very heavy import bill. It has protested, and protested publicly, about the imposition of this move. The Government has said, `We'll make a transfer by the Department of Finance for the costs involved so that, at the end of the day, the Department of Defence does not suffer any financial penalty for this change to the Act'. That is really a very glib bureaucratic answer to the problem. Every time the Commonwealth Government puts its sticky fingers on money it costs the taxpayers money.

If the Department of Defence, or any other Commonwealth department, will have to pay this fee equivalent to customs duty, it will have to create its own empire which it will have to staff with personnel and resources. There is a considerable cost in that. The fee is then added on to the value of the goods. It is ultimately reimbursed by the Department of Finance to the extent that the Department is out of pocket on the whole thing. It is all pointless; it is just building costs into government administration. We will not quibble with that point and we certainly will not oppose that clause of the Bill. On behalf of the Liberal and National parties I wish the Bill a speedy passage. We will be supporting the amendments proposed by the Australian Democrats with respect to the reduction and elimination of duty on certain classes of goods.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today the Senate is debating the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1990 and cognate Bills. This Bill amends the Customs Tariff Act 1987. The principal amendments are: the removal of duty on certain articles of rubber apparel, protein concentrates, coal, tar, pitch and certain tractors; and removal of the exemption of duty-free entries of goods for Commonwealth departments and instrumentalities. It does not reduce new tender duty rates for certain goods in the textiles, clothing and footwear industries from 1 March 1990 extending to 22 February 1991 as part of the long term plan in the TCF industries to reduce tariffs over time.

SPEECH.PARA: The levels of assistance for TCF industries are the highest in Australian manufacturing. The Industry Commission has estimated that the cost to consumers of protection to the industry is approximately $1 billion per annum. The plan was introduced on 1 March 1989 and is scheduled to run to June 1995. Its stated aim is to make TCF industries more competitive internationally by restructuring through such measures as a gradual removal of tariff quotas, positive assistance programs for industry restructuring and a shift to a tariff-only system.

There is some evidence that the textiles, clothing and footwear industries are currently in a fairly bad way. There is no doubt that high interest rates, the high dollar and an Australian economy in recession have added to the problems faced by the industry. But there also seems to be a fair amount of evidence that the industry is a little sluggish in taking up the opportunities offered by the plan. I note an article in the Australian Financial Review of 16 October in which Julie Power points out that the response by the industry to positive assistance programs has indeed been lethargic. The strategies are designed to improve performance, accelerate restructuring and boost export opportunities. The available assistance includes the provision of highly subsidised overseas trips to learn export marketing skills. These had to be axed after very poor attendance at the first course.

Another initiative was the offer of an accountant from Price Waterhouse to assist with export and domestic cost structures at the cost of $200 per day compared with the normal rate of $1,200 per day. As it happened, not one company took up the offer. This appears to show a complete lack of commitment by most of the industry to taking on board the aims of the TCF plan.

However, we should not be too hasty. If a plan is not working and people are not taking up the offers being made, the question inevitably arises: has the Government chosen the right policy initiatives? Has it made the right offers? Do they really suit this particular industry? It is fairly clear that, as we move into the next decade, we must achieve an economy that is self-sufficient and sustainable. We will not do that if we demolish all our home-grown industries, particularly the textile industry, which, to such a large extent, is dependent on the wool that our primary industry is producing. The aim of the textile industry and indeed of the Government should be to increase the amount of wool that we can process in our country rather than import carpets, apparel and other items, which means that we ship the raw material overseas, people are then employed in foreign countries, and we ship back the finished products.

Before we judge the industry too harshly and reduce tariffs too quickly, we should review the activities that the Government has offered to the industry. We should review the whole strategy of the plan. It appears from the very indifferent performance so far that the plan requires thorough review before we kill off our industries, put our people out of employment and further damage our primary industries.

I now turn to the amendments circulated in my name. They sought to implement the recommendations made in the Industry Commission report No. 3 dated 18 July 1990, entitled Aids and Appliances for People with Disabilities. This report recommends changes to the tariffs applying to aids and appliances used by disabled people. In fact, most disability equipment is free of duty, either substantially or through tariff concessions. Major exceptions are wheelchairs and pacemakers, as well as mass produced orthopaedic footwear and incontinence aids.

The amendments that were circulated to lower the tariffs on those items received a positive response from the Government. I am in possession of a customs order to take effect from 1 January next year that states that wheelchairs, pacemakers and defribillators are made free of customs duty, at a somewhat more accelerated rate than I suggested in my amendment. I thank the Minister responsible for taking that action. It is extremely appropriate. In view of that, I now give notice that I withdraw my amendments.

There are two items that the Government has not taken on board in its commitment. These are the orthopaedic footwear and incontinence aids. Having had some consultations on those items with the Department, I accept that there are some difficulties in this area and that these matters will be picked up early in the new year. If the Government does not move I will, of course, reintroduce my amendments.

But I am gratified that the Government has taken this action, and I thank the Opposition for its preparedness, as Senator MacGibbon announced in his speech, to support my amendments. I believe that we must take account of the needs of disabled people. I remind the Senate once again of the John Rolls principle: that a community is judged by the way it treats its most disadvantaged members. I believe that this is a very gratifying outcome to the amendments I have attempted to introduce.

I now turn to one of the other Bills which we are debating as an allied Bill, the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill 1990. This Bill has been referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, and after a couple of meetings the situation now is that the Australian Democrats will support it. The issue that is raised by the Bill is the acknowledged retrospectivity of the Government's attempts in that Bill to rectify a drafting mistake which happened in 1984. It is acknowledged without a doubt that retrospectivity is to be avoided wherever possible. However, there are obvious exceptions, and I point to the fact that one Bill, which makes similar provisions and will come before the Senate shortly, and which will be passed, I understand, by all parties without dissent, retrospectively ensures that weapons, guns, landmines and other equipment which is currently held by the Australian Customs Service, under admittedly defective legislation, is not released into the community.

In the case of the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill we are dealing with a similar situation. The claim by Esso-BHP for the return of funds which it has paid as an excise on oil between 1984 and 1990, since amended to a lesser amount for just 12 months-the total amount would have been $200m and the lesser amount is approximately $30m-rests on a draftsman's error. In the legislation which was introduced in 1984, by-law 78 was repealed but the effect of the by-law which the Minister intended to continue was not transposed in the legislation. There is ample evidence of the intention of the Minister to do so. There are press statements, second reading speeches and explanatory memoranda which state very clearly that the classification of the oil which attracts the higher excise should not be reviewed. Nevertheless, by the omission of the relevant words, on a strict legal interpretation, oil produced since 1984 would be classified as new oil and under these circumstances BHP would be entitled to receive $30m of taxpayers' funds.

The Australian Democrats believe that we should take account of the substance of the legislation, which is clearly demonstrated by the documents supporting the Minister's intention at the time. We believe that we should not allow a drafting mistake to remove $30m in funds from the public purse. We believe that this is a case where the party paying the higher level of excise has not done it in any way under protest or under the assumption that it has been paying a wrong amount. During the committee proceedings I pushed that question quite clearly. I asked whether there had been a very specific protest in relation to the payment of the higher excise and the answer, as the Hansard will reveal, was quite clearly no.

I am not suggesting that non-protest necessarily means that the taxpayer, in this case Esso-BHP, has agreed to the payment of the higher excise. However, it is evidence of the fact that at the time and during the whole period between 1984 and March 1990 all parties were of the view that the legislation was in place which obliged Esso-BHP to pay the higher excise. During all of that time Esso-BHP has proceeded in business and has no doubt taken account of that liability in calculating its costs and managing its business. It is perhaps instructive to look briefly at the profits made by that company in those 10 years. They range from $200m in 1980 to $492m in 1985, and to $395m in 1990. I advert to these figures only to show that the taxpayer did not suffer any deprivation in that period.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is immaterial.

—It is not immaterial because the situation would be different if the legislation were changed in substance and if the taxpayer had been severely disadvantaged in the intervening period. That obviously is a factor that would go to whether or not an exception to retrospectivity should be made. As I have said previously, exceptions to retrospectivity have been agreed to on previous occasions and the Opposition is going to agree to one in the current session of Parliament. Clearly it is not a situation where retrospectivity is, of itself, abhorrent. It is as a general principle, but there are exceptions. In our view, this is one such exception and I am sure that my colleague Senator Coulter will go further into the detail of this Bill and the reason for our stance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating as allied Bills the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill 1990 and the Petroleum Excise (Prices) Amendment Bill 1990. The Middle East is in turmoil over oil and as a result we are seeing world peace balanced at this stage on a knife edge. The Middle East conflict has had a dramatic effect on the cost of petroleum and petroleum products in Australia. The West Texas intermediate crude oil price has risen from around $21 per barrel in August to settle at $27 today, having peaked at around $40.65 in mid-October. It is in this volatile climate that further adjustments are being made to our own petroleum industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The Excise Tariff Amendment Bill 1990, which was introduced into the House of Representatives on 10 October, has three parts. The first part seeks to make a number of amendments consequential to the introduction of separate volume weighted average of realised (VOLWARE) prices for different oilfields. It is consequential to amendments contained in the Petroleum Excise (Prices) Amendment Bill 1990. The second part of the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill relates to the adjustment of the excise duty for naturally occurring liquefied petroleum gas. The third part deals with the definition of new and old oil and has complex and far-reaching ramifications for the oil industry. I intend to deal at length with this aspect of the Bill, but first I will deal with the first two aspects.

As I have mentioned, the first part of the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill 1990 also relates to the Petroleum Excise (Prices) Amendment Bill 1990 and it seeks to amend the Petroleum Excise (Prices) Act 1987. The principal Petroleum Excise (Prices) Act applies to offshore areas producing excisable petroleum and, as such, has been confined to Bass Strait. The Opposition is not opposed to the legislation in the broad sense. However a number of aspects do give us concern and should be thoroughly debated.

It is imperative that the oil industry is given as much encouragement as possible to step up its exploration for oil in Australia. Sadly, encouragement has been lacking in recent years and our oilfields which supply our domestic oil are in decline. This must be reversed. The oil industry is on the horns of a dilemma. The view has been taken that Australia is not a very prospective area. The attitude of people such as Senator Cook, when he was Minister for Resources, was to make the best of the secondary taxes while they were available.

If, on the other hand, Australia is considered to be prospective, complex secondary taxes are imposed by governments just in case someone makes a major discovery. Whatever the scenario, it is a no-win situation for oil explorers but, more importantly, it is a no-win situation for Australia as complex secondary tax regimes drive explorers and potential explorers to countries other than Australia. It is the recent view of oil geologists that prospective basins in Australia are under-explored when compared with similar structures overseas.

Irrespective of the arguments mounted for secondary taxes, the major reason for the relatively low level of oil exploration in Australia is undoubtedly the tax regime as compared with other countries. As our domestic oil reserves continue to dwindle, that regime must change by necessity. With limited capital and competing ends for that capital, it is inevitable that it will be directed to the most attractive competitor. Decisions which have to be made on that basis will always be costs, markets and perceived political stability.

Before I continue, I must clarify that the two Bills we are debating today are separate from the resource rent tax which, if passed by the Parliament, will be extended to Bass Strait from 1 July 1990, replacing the current excise and royalty regime. As a transitional arrangement, the Bass Strait producers will continue to be liable for excise and royalty until the amending legislation is enacted. The Bills we are debating relate to the three areas that I have mentioned previously, which I will expand on.

The Excise Tariff Amendment Bill 1990 provides for onshore oilfields to pay excise if the oilfield exceeds the $30m threshold. This part of the Bill also provides the facility for calculating different volume weighted average of realised prices for sales of crude oil from different oil producing regions. (Quorum formed)

Just before the quorum was called I was talking about VOLWARE. This amendment anticipates that Jackson oilfield will exceed 30 million barrels early in 1991, so production above this limit would be excisable. The coalition has been advised, however, that no excise will ever be recovered from Jackson because production is expected to fall lower than the approximately three million barrel annual limit below which no excise is payable.

The Opposition-the Liberal and National parties-do not oppose the intent of this legislation. However, we do not agree with the proposition as it stands that the legislation be retrospective to the end of 1987. The Government argues that this is to save the publication of a Commonwealth of Australia Gazette item dealing with VOLWARE prices for an interim period for Bass Strait. To date, no oilfield has produced beyond the 30 million barrel threshold, except Bass Strait and that is covered by the original Act.

The Government is now trying to legislate because the Jackson field might reach the first requirement of 30 million barrels. Surely it would be far better in that case to make the commencement for this provision at some date in the future, not from 1987 because it brings in the retrospectivity element.

The Government has no justification for making this Bill retrospective. It would make far more sense to make payment for this excise prospective from the date of royal assent; there is no monetary effect involved. Consequently, I foreshadow that the Opposition will move an amendment in the committee stage of the Bill to ensure that this aspect of the legislation commences from the date of royal assent-that it is prospective, not retrospective.

The second part of the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill is to increase the rate of excise on naturally occurring liquefied petroleum gas (LPG). This is adjusted each year on 1 April and 1 October in accordance with the liquefied petroleum gas excise policy announced in April 1980. It is not our intention to interfere in any way with the LPG changes in the legislation. The excise rate will be amended with effect from 1 April 1990 from zero to $5.78 per kilolitre. The increase reflects the higher export prices obtained for LPG over the six months to March 1990.

The third part of this legislation gives the Opposition grave concern. Indeed, what the Government has tried to pass through the Parliament should be of concern to every senator and anyone who does business with this Government. The Government says it is moving to correct what the Minister calls a technical error-this was regurgitated earlier by Senator Spindler-to the definition of new oil. However, its course of action in remedying it has serious ramifications, as the classification of oil from the 10-year-old Tuna oilfield in Bass Strait has been the subject of a dispute between the joint partners-BHP, Esso and the Government.

Crude oil is categorised as old or new oil, depending on when the oilfield was discovered and brought into production. The definition of new oil was altered in 1984 and because of the Government's legislative inefficiencies it has come to light that the previous amendment had an unintended effect; that is, to allow some oilfields that had previously been classified under an excise by-law as old oil to be classified as new oil. Right from the word go it was new oil-and I do not think anyone will dispute that.

There is no doubt the Government has handled the Tuna L oilfield in Bass Strait in a very clumsy manner. It has tried to deal with a very complex issue using piecemeal legislation. In this legislation it has tried to retrospectively legislate away the rights of the Bass Strait partners. But worse, it also intended to use its legislative powers to interfere with the course of hearings in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT), which is the body empowered to consider these disputes.

This is contrary to the longstanding view of the Liberal and National parties that the Commonwealth should not legislate against potentially adverse findings of bodies who have been empowered to resolve such matters, still less try to change the effect of judicial determinations once made-a very important point. At this point I cite the fifth edition of Odgers, which quotes Jordan J. in Ex parte Bread Manufacturers Ltd: Re Truth and Sportman Ltd and another:
It is of extreme public interest that no conduct should be permitted which is likely to prevent a litigant in a court of justice from having his case tried free from all matter of prejudice.

In the case of the legislation we are debating here today, the prejudice is extreme indeed. The courts and, following them, the Senate have always allowed that the public interest might be held to justify a breach of the sub judice rule. But in this case the only interest in the matter is whether the litigants ought properly to have had their case heard and determined.

The legislation had two elements to it which the Opposition found repugnant. First, it was clearly retrospective and, secondly, it would have pre-empted an appeal to the AAT-I might say, determined today-against charges for excise which under 1984 legislation were not lawful. The appeal was listed today. The AAT was told that the Commonwealth did not contest the matter, and the AAT then awarded BHP and Esso what they had claimed. I think the Australian Democrats should take this on board, because it is quite apparent that the effect of this legislation, if it is passed without the amendments that we will be moving in the committee stage, will be that the damages awarded by the AAT will be withdrawn.

This Bill was referred to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs to enable evidence to be heard from both the public servants and one of the Bass Strait partners, and to consider Opposition amendments. Prior to that, the Standing Committee on Scrutiny of Bills flagged the objectionable retrospective provisions of the Bill in its Alert Digest No. 8 of 1990. In a subsequent report tabled on 7 November, the Scrutiny of Bills Committee included this quote from a submission from BHP:

We consider that the provisions of this Bill should concern your Committee because it will make rights, liberties, or obligations unduly dependent upon non-reviewable administrative decisions, and that retrospectively for 10 years. In the very act of seeking the review open to us, the Government, by this legislation, proposed to take that right away from us.

We submit that the legislative principle is the same, whether it is a corporation like BHP or a private citizen. If the Government can persuade the Parliament that this is a legitimate action, it will be easier for the Government to do it again.

The Liberal-National Party agrees with those sentiments. In the Committee, when discussing the definition of `new' oil and `old' oil, I understand that the Government and BHP, the two parties to the action, both agreed that Tuna L was in fact `new' oil. There is no dispute about that. This means that the Bass Strait partners should not have been required to pay the higher excise. The Government claims that the legislation is necessary to save it paying out over collections. While the Government initially claimed the amount would be $200m, BHP believed it was entitled to one year's overpayment, an amount of $30m, which in fact is the amount that has been determined by the AAT today.

To reinforce the limit of potential liability to the Government and to preserve the principle of preventing governments from retrospectively legislating to prevent citizens from appealing against illegal impositions of government, an alternative amendment was put to the Committee which would have guaranteed the outcome if the AAT found in favour of the Bass Strait partners-and the AAT has so found today.

It is interesting that when a vote was taken in the Committee on this particular amendment it was a straw vote and quite inconclusive. The result appeared to be three-all and apparently the amendment was lost. As Hansard shows, however, it is clear that Government members themselves were very reluctantly acting under directions and thus harboured the concerns of the Opposition about setting this quite disgraceful precedent.
It is significant that the Chairman declined to exercise a casting vote and that Senator Giles, when asked how she would vote, responded-and I quote from Hansard:
What am I instructed to say?

I remind the Democrats that, by not supporting the Opposition amendment, they are party to condoning retrospective legislation to remove the rights of Australian citizens. Under our system in Australia, compared with the United States-this is where Senator Spindler seems to have some difficulty-it is the legislation which is paramount.

A cornerstone of the stability of our parliamentary system is the ability of Australians to rely on legislation. For the Democrats to support the Government and not the Opposition on this matter is tantamount to repudiation. As I said in earlier debate, the players are absolutely immaterial; they do not matter. What is material is the principle. Retrospectivity is either supported or it is not, and the Liberal and National parties will not support retrospectivity.

A few years ago, the High Court considered a matter not dissimilar from the one now at hand. In the case of Lee v. Watson, 1979, 144 Commonwealth Law Reports 374, the question arose whether a technical failure to make certain foreign exchange regulations available for sale affected their validity. The High Court found they did. The Chief Justice said:
To bind the citizen by law, the terms of which he has no means of knowing, would be a mark of tyranny'.

Clearly, however, the law was defective. The Government of the day sought to amend it as soon as possible. It is interesting that my colleague Senator Durack, then the Attorney-General, brought in legislation to correct the error. But, unlike the present Government, he was careful to omit from his Bill any retrospective application to the people who at the time had a case before the High Court. The then Attorney-General's action was correct, just as that of the present Government is totally incorrect.

The Taxation Institute of Australia (TIA) has also strongly condemned the Government's action. In a press release headed, `Government's action sets dangerous precedent for taxpayers', the President of the Taxation Institute of Australia, Mr Richard Buchanan, said:

The Government's hasty retrospective `technical correction' to the Excise Tariff Act 1921, aimed specifically at BHP Petroleum, must be viewed as making the role of courts and tribunals redundant, and possibly even interfering with the rule of law'.

Mr Buchanan was also quoted as calling the Government's move as an `unwarranted intrusion on the Australian system of justice and fair play'. He went on to say that `the TIA was not so much supporting BHP Petroleum'-and I think that is important; it really is immaterial who it is-`as alerting the electorate to a matter of grave concern'. The TIA press release went on to say this:
Mr Buchanan said BHP Petroleum was taking the correct legal action and yet while this was going on the Government had manipulated the system to suit its own end.

It is crystal clear from the reasons that I have outlined that the Liberal and National parties have some grave concerns about the legislation. We are opposed to the retrospective elements of the legislation and will oppose the second reading by moving the following amendment:
Leave out all words after ``That'', insert:

``the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1990 be now read a second time, and that consideration of the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill 1990 and the Petroleum Excise (Prices) Amendment Bill 1990 be deferred until the money which is determined to be due and payable to Bass Strait crude oil producers by the decision of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal on 12 December 1990 has been ascertained and refunded to the producers.

That is a fairly important amendment, because it means that, even though the AAT today has found on behalf of BHP and Esso, the Bass Strait partners, if this legislation goes through unamended, it will take away the decision which was brought down by the AAT. I move this amendment because one of the improper and unacceptable aspects of this Bill is that it was introduced to pre-empt an appeal to the existing legislation to the AAT.

As I said earlier, what is material is that the appeal be allowed to proceed to its absolute conclusion and that the outcome be given effect without it being nullified by this legislation. I hope that the Democrats listen carefully to the point my colleagues and I are making about this amendment. If they do, I believe they will have some opportunity to salvage a semblance of respect for the principles to which they claim to aspire. The acid test is what they do when hard decisions on principle must be made. We in the Liberal and National parties are giving them this opportunity in this amendment. If they do not take that opportunity, any talk in the future by the Democrats about principles will be treated with the derision it will richly deserve.

They could well make a phone call to their founder, Mr Don Chipp, who claimed to have founded the Australian Democrats on the grounds of honesty and principle. I am sure that, if they do, he will tell them that they have been compromised. The Democrats may care to cast their minds back to the numerous occasions recorded in Hansard when Mr Chipp expressed his abhorrence for retrospective legislation. His utter dislike for retrospective legislation is well documented. I will cite a few of them. He included his Democrat colleagues on 6 March 1984 during debate on the tax assessment amendment legislation when he said:

Even those in this chamber who favour retrospective legislation-and they do not include me, Senator Haines or Senator Macklin-would realise that it sets dangerous precedents and undermines the rule of law. Therefore, they must be prepared to make out a very good case as to why legislation should be made retrospective.
I am sure the Democrats stated reasons for supporting this legislation. I quote Senator Spindler during the Standing Committee hearing on this latest legislation:

Our votes were based on the fairly clear evidence which we have obtained at the last Committee session that it was the clearly enunciated intention of government to legislate that the oil in question be old oil carrying the higher excise duty.

He went on in this vein for a short while, in spite of the fact that the Chairman had said only a short while earlier that the Government and BHP, the two parties, both agreed that it was new oil. So here we had the two parties saying it was new oil and Senator Spindler taking a different view. I am sure this argument would not pass Don Chipp's criterion when he said that a very good case had to be made out as to why legislation should be retrospective. In the same speech, Mr Chipp had this to say:
I will not have a bar of the principle of retrospectivity at any price. Therefore, notwithstanding how good the reason, I reject it.
Further he said:
We agree with this legislation. The only part of the legislation with which we disagree is its retrospective aspect.
So he agreed with the legislation but not the retrospective aspect. A few years earlier, in November 1982, he said on the tax assessment legislation:

Good heavens: give politicians the chance to legislate retrospectively and we will open a Pandora's Box. I find this quite frightening . . . I am prepared to go to the barricades in respect of this matter.
If the Democrats do not heed their founder's warning and take the opportunity we are giving them today, any talk in the future by them about principles will be treated with derision.

EXCISE TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL 1990
Policy background.
The 1983 Policy
* On 30-June 1983 the Government announced changes to the excise arrangements which would ``remove the distinction between discoveries made by exploration and development drilling.''

* In future ``new'' oil application would be assessed on the basis of whether the oil was discovered after 17 September 1975 and whether it was present as a naturally occurring discrete accumulation irrespective of the objective of the discovery well.
* This meant that the Minister's determination in 1980 would have been wrong if made any time after 1983.
* However, the Minister said earlier decisions ``would not be reviewed.''
* Amendments to the Excise Tariff Act came into effect on 1 July 1984 and By-law 78 was revoked on 30 June 1984.
* The effect of these changes was to classify any crude oil discovered after 17 September 1975 as ``new'' oil.
* From then on, there was likewise no need for the Minister to make a determination and there is no doubt that Tuna Field oil falls within the new definition, and has always done so.
* Although the Minister had said earlier decision ``would not be reviewed'', the 1984 legislation did not so provide.
The 1990 refund claim
* Although BHP-Esso did not exercise various options open to them to protest the Minister's decision, they remained unhappy about paying the higher rate of excise.
* In 1990 they made a claim for refund to the Collector of Customs.

* The maximum amount that can be refunded (see Customs Regulation 53) is excise for 12 months-somewhere between $15-20m. The Government has said a ``contingent'' liability of $200m could be involved but the law would not allow that much to be refunded.
The 1975 Policy

* In September 1975, the then Prime Minister announced a new policy on crude oil pricing applicable to oil discovered on or after 17 September 1975. The policy distinguished between ``old'' oil and ``new'' oil, the latter being oil discovered after 17 September 1975.
* Excise By-law 78 was gazetted on 7 June 1977. It said that the definition of ``new'' oil

``applies to stabilised crude petroleum obtained from a naturally occurring discrete accumulation discovered on or after 18 August 1976 as a result of drilling a well which, after drilling, is classified by the Minister within one of the following categories; namely:
* New field discovery;
* new pool (pay) discovery;
* deeper pool discovery; or
* shallower pool discovery.''
* It will be seen that the decision by the Minister to classify the oil establishes its category. It is a Ministerial discretion, not reviewable by the Parliament.
* This by-law, as made by the Minister, meant that item 17 of the Excise Tariff Act 1921 applied to the oil.
The 1980 Decision
* In 1978 Development drilling in the Tuna Field began. One of the wells encountered previously undiscovered discrete accumulations of crude oil.

* A letter from Esso Australia dated 21 January 1980 to the Department of National Development asked the Minister for a declaration under the Crude Oil Pricing Policy that the oil so found was ``new''.
* On 29 August 1980, the Department said that the Minister had refused the application.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 16 October 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What precisely is the mathematical relationship used by the department to relate medical impairment with incapacity for work to determine eligibility for the invalid pension.
(2) If there is no such mathematical relationship, precisely what rules do officers of the department use to relate medical impairment to incapacity.

(3) Under these rules does the department consider that it is possible that an applicant for the invalid pension could apply for the pension at one office of the department only to be told s/he is ineligible, but if s/he approached some other office, it may be the view of that office that the applicant is indeed eligible.

(4) With regard to the new Disability Support Pension, which requires a minimum medical impairment of 20 per cent, how precisely will departmental officers relate this level of impairment (or any other level) to an ``incapacity to work full time for full award wages in the foreseeable future''.
(5) How is an incapacity to work full time for full award wages in the foreseeable future to be determined.

(6) What will be the ASO levels of the departmental officers charged with determining incapacity and who outside the department will be consulted to assist in determining eligibility, and at what level.

(7) What percentage of invalid pensioners who were in receipt of the pension as at 21 August 1990 will have their eligibility reviewed within the first year of their being in receipt of the Disability Support Pension.
(8) With as much detail as possible, for existing invalid pensioners, what differences will there be between the invalid pension and the Disability Support Pension.
(9) How much extra in administration costs per pensioner and in 1989-90 dollars will the Disability Support Pension be compared with the administration costs for the invalid pension per pensioner.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) &(2) The Social Security Act presently requires that a person must be at least 85% permanently incapacitated for work and that at least 50% of the permanent incapacity for work must be directly caused by a permanent physical or mental impairment. A permanent incapacity for work is measured by reference to medical and non-medical (socio-economic) factors. The impairment causation requirement means that the non-medical factors cannot outweigh the medical factors.

Once the primary test of permanent incapacity for work is met, the decision-maker must then determine the extent to which the person's impairment(s) contributed to that permanent incapacity. An impairment level of 30% or more will usually mean that the second test is also met (i.e. that the incapacity arises primarily from impairment). Careful consideration needs to be given to cases where the impairment level is between 15% and 30%. Where the impairment is 15% or less it is very unlikely that the impairment is the major factor causing the incapacity. A critical evaluation of the extent to which the impairment is causing the incapacity must be made in all cases where non-medical factors are significant in contributing to a person's incapacity.

(3) The correct application of Departmental guidelines should ensure consistency of decision making for invalid pension eligibility purposes. In deciding whether the applicant satisfies the 85% permanent incapacity rule and the impairment causation requirement, Department of Social Security (DSS) officers are required to apply a set of standard national policy guidelines. The consistent application of these guidelines is achieved through the process of cross determination of claims within regional offices, regular quality control and common training for regional office pension assessors. Authorised Review Officers are also available in Area Offices to review decisions. Feedback from them helps to ensure consistency in decision-making.

In making qualitative decisions DSS officers are also required to have regard to an independently determined impairment rating. Because impairment is a medical concept the ratings are decided impartially by a Commonwealth Medical Officer (CMO) employed by the Department of Community Services and Health. The CMO undertakes individual examinations of applicants and assigns an impairment rating in accordance with a standard set of measurements and tables.

(4) &5 It is intended that the new eligibility criteria for Disability Support Pension will be based on two separate components: a minimum 20% level of impairment and an assessment of inability to work which is due wholly or substantially to a physical, intellectual or psychiatric impairment.
Those who do not meet the 20% impairment threshold will be automatically rejected for Disability Support Pension.

Where the minimum impairment level is satisfied, eligibility will be determined on the basis of a person's work force potential. ``Work'' will be defined to include full time and substantial part time work. Inability to work must be long term (that is for the ``foreseeable future'', to be defined as not less than two years). A delegate of the Secretary will decide eligibility on the basis of residence, age, income and assets and:
(i) whether the person is totally unfit for any work (including work the person currently does not have the skills to undertake) because of the medical condition alone;
Grant if Yes
(ii) if there are any areas of the labour market still open to the person, whether he/she has the skills to do this kind of work and access to such work is not precluded by the medical condition;
Reject if Yes

(iii) if the person does not have the skills, whether it is reasonable to expect him/her to obtain the skills. Acceptable reasons for not obtaining skills are limited to lack of access (caused by the medical condition) and age;
Reject if Yes
(iv) if there may be eligibility after steps (ii) and (iii), whether eligibility arises primarily from medical impairment.
Reject if No

(6) In the majority of cases, where the determination is not straight forward specialist staff in DSS (Disability Officers) will be responsible for determining eligibility for Disability Support Pension. Their classification level is to be agreed between DSS and the Department of Finance (DoF). The DoF is conducting a work value assessment before the two departments meet to resolve the issue. The funding for the positions has been set at the ASO 5 level, as an interim arrangement, with a commitment for additional funding if the agreed classification level is higher than the ASO 5 level.

Panels convened by the Disability Officers and made up of staff from DEET and DCSH will be the main source of advice when a Disability Officer is assessing a person's ability to work. The DEET officers will be at the same ASO level as the Disability Officers and the DCSH staff will be a professional grade, equivalent in salary terms to a level between ASO 5 and ASO 6.
Disability Officers will be able to consult widely in making assessments and treating doctors, specialists and other experts may be contacted.

(7) It is estimated that approximately two per cent of existing invalid pensioners at 21 August 1990 will have medical reviews scheduled and, therefore, will have their eligibility reviewed within the first 12 months following the introduction of the Disability Support Pension. In addition, an expected 30 per cent of those granted invalid pension after the Budget announcement and before the 1 October changes will be progressively reviewed from 1 October 1991. Other existing invalid pensioners may opt to participate in the new Disability Support Pension system.

(8) Invalid pensioners current at 1 October 1991 will be automatically transferred to Disability Support Pension. Those scheduled for a review after that date will be reviewed under the new criteria. Those transferred will be able to take advantage of provisions that encourage part time work and may volunteer for training and rehabilitation assessment.

(9) In most respects the cost of administering the Disability Support Pension will be similar to that currently incurred in administering the Invalid Pension, Sheltered Employment Allowance and Rehabilitation Allowance. The major additional factor which will be brought to bear on the administration of Disability Support Pension is the role of the Disability Officers.
In 1991-92 it is estimated that the cost of these Officers will average $12.90 per Disability Support Pensioner. In 1989-90 dollar terms the 1991-92 costs of these advisors will be $5.1 million.

The new system is intended to help the maximum possible number of applicants for pension to be rehabilitated and be economically and socially active. In the longer term it should reduce the number of people receiving pension for life and, therefore, be cost effective and in the interest of the individuals concerned.
